author: Ed B.

description:
Burger was good but service was bad.. Like bad service.. 
Maybe it's because I'm here on a saturday at 3:00 am but either way.. My food order came wrong more than once and also there server just dropped the food off and left never to check and see if we was good.. Also appetizer came same time with meal really..?
author: Stven A S.

description: This place is a great to grab food at any hour, I've been here many times and never been disappointed. Getting work done here at any crazy hour has been partially my reason for visiting. I've even brought along family or friends to dine with. They have delicious burgers and most of the time isn't too crazy, however during special events and peak hours its good to leave in haste. Most people come here for as good a reason's as i do. The service is very good.
author: Daniel A.

description: We ate here at 1am on our honeymoon after a long trip and were pleasantly surprised at the great service and yummy food. We thoroughly enjoyed our mac and cheese and patty melt. The perfect late night meal after some beer and wine!!!!!
author: Michelle M.

description:
I found this 24 hour diner after going to the Infusion club. This diner gets busy! It was packed but were able to get seated right away. They have a wide variets of foods on their menu and I love that they serve breakfast 24 hours a day. I have to say this place has the best diner food ever! I ordered 2 over easy eggs with sourdough bread, bacon and hashbrowns. It was amazing! The sourdough bread was one of the best sourdough bread I ever had! Everything else was cooked to perfection! The portions they give you are just perfect!

The only things that sort of sucked was that the food took forever because it was busy, the bathrooms were dirty and the chili cheese fries that me and my girls tried needed more cheese. But my main meal was sooo good that this place still gets 5 stars!
author: Emily P.

description:
I work in the area and passed by this hole in the wall for the past 6 yrs.  I always scoffed at it...eww...looks old and scary.
My co-worker convinced me to try it out and I was totally blown away by their quick service and delicious All American food.  It was just a to go order but it was the best chili cheese dog and fries!  

I saw alot of patrons eating inside young and old .  So bad on me for judging the restaurant by how it looks outside.    They serve breakfast all day so will have to give it a try next time =)
author: J B.

description: Only been here late at night when other options were few to nil. OK for a greasy spoon / truck stop diner and perfect for some fried foods to soak up the fumes. Not my first choice in the daytime when other restaurants are open. I don't frequent this place now that I am a responsible adult who is home by 10pm, maybe 11pm or 12am at the latest.
author: Cece E.

description: BEST mac and cheese i've ever had, at the shittiest 24-hr diner in existence. You can't call yourself a 24hr restaurant if I can't order your bomb-ass mac & cheese past 11pm thats just unnecessary & f'd up imo. i'm VERY upset. 24 hrs? not really.....
author: Chessie C.

description:
Our mission was to find a local haven with good food. How to accomplish said mission? Just ask the locals on the street. Should be an adventure.

The first guy we asked told us to go to Pinecrest. Said he eats there at least 2X/ day. He then gushed for about 5 minutes about this joint. Only reason he stopped is because our stomachs started growling. Loudly.

We get to Pinecrest and the line is out the door. Which isn't hard because the place is small. But when there's a line, I see that as a good thing. The line is filled with locals and I began making friends (what can I say? I'm a social person who doesn't mind talking to creepy looking guys in food lines). The locals gave me a run down on every diner in the area and why this one was the best. They told me to get an omelette and then go back to my hotel for a nap because I would be stuffed after.

They were right. The Greek omelet with spinach, tomato and feta cheese made with egg whites was yummy! Flavor in every bite.

I also tried my friends Denver omelet. Yum. 

While the line out the door might seem daunting, it moved quickly. We were given the nod by the makeshift hostess (pretty much the guy at the cash register just pointed at an empty table and told us to sit.) our waitress came by within seconds and we were scarfing food within 10 minutes. Perfect way to have a brunch in the city.
author: Tia B.

description: Great food and prices. I will tell my friends to make sure to dine here.  pancakes and the omelets are wonderful.  great staff as well.
author: Brent D.

description:
One of the best diners I've EVER been to on either coast.
Staff is super courteous. Food delicious. Ambiance like super old school America.
author: Varun V.

description:
A classic, old school diner.  We were prepared for typical greasy diner food and were very very pleasantly surprised.

Good diverse menu with something that should appeal to everyone.  I ordered the mediterranean plate.  Chicken was great, the vegetables in the greek salad were crisp and fresh.  My wife ordered the chicken gyro.  It was massive and good.  +1 point for having a picture of each entree on the menu.
author: Aaron G.

description: Had the hot links and eggs. Excellent. Sitting at the counter, I had the chance to see a few other orders. The crumbled bleu burger looked delish. Also the NY Strip looked pretty tasty. Good crowd but not packed. Friendly service. Would have went 5 star but no N/A beers.
author: Brian B.

description:
A Pox on Pinecrest!
A Pox on Pinecrest!!
A POX ON PINECREST!!!

Against my better judgment, I decided to get breakfast at the Pinecrest this morning. It was fairly empty, so I presumed I had my choice of booths. There was certainly no sign to ask me to wait to be seated. When I sat down in one of the front booths and started to take my jacket off, I was told summarily to get up and take the solo booth next to the front door. I did what I was told.

As I sat in the smaller booth, I noticed a gust of cold wind would hit me when anybody came in or out of the door. My napkin would fly from my lap to the floor every single time. I ordered. I ate. I was ignored for coffee refills because I was completely out of sight from the waitress. Meanwhile, two individual diners came through the door. The same two waitresses who dictated where I sat told each of the two men to sit wherever they like. Each sat in their own large-size booths.

When I was finally given the check after being forced to flag her down, I fumbled for my cash and found I had just the amount for the check plus one penny. I then decided to write a helpful note on the check for the waitress...

"Dear Waitress,

I am unclear why you forced me to sit in this lousy booth when you let two single-person diners sit wherever they wanted - including the booth in which I first sat. Shame on you for your unfair seating practices. Shame on you for discriminating against me. Shame on you for favoring one customer over another.

Yours sincerely,
An Unsatisfied Customer

P.S. Here is a penny I feel you deserve for your unfair service. Invest wisely."

Needless to say, I won't be returning. Regarding the food, I ordered the $9.95 Continental Omelette, which had bits of packaged sausage, mushroom, tomatoes and melted American cheese (see photo). Meh....and any aspiration to be like Max's across the street is beyond ludicrous. The eggs came with some oily hash browns and sourdough toast. The toast was the best part of the meal.

FOOD - 2.5 stars...infamous greasy spoon lives down to its name and overcharges to boot
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...in severe need of an upgrade decor-wise and people-wise
SERVICE - (negative 5)...enough said
TOTAL - 1 star...We all deserve to be treated with respect!...Even if they served French Laundry-level cuisine, no one should tolerate that kind of indifference...NO ONE!
author: Ed U.

description:
I was just up in sf for nye and after we went out my boyfriend and I were starving this place was right across the street from the club we went to.  We went to the door initially because it had the shortest line out of all the places around there at 3 am.  It took us around 15 minutes to sit down at the counter and then it was about an hour-hour and a half wait for our food but it was WORTH the wait.  I got the chicken gyro and it honestly had the best of everything in it! awesome grilled chicken, pita bread that was made on the grill in front of me and made to order, the cucumber and tomatoes were marinated in an awesomely tasty dill sauce and the tazikki sauce was out of this world!

This place is 24 hours and the guys who work there are some the hardest working people I have ever seen!  Not only was it NYE, it was 3 am, and the staff was dealing with drunk people who were being very demanding. The one guy who was taking everyone's order had such an awesome memory it was crazy despite the fact that he was running on coffee it seemed (saw him with a thermos).

I would have given this place 5 stars but the wait for most people would be a problem. The food was 5 starts for sure though!!!!
author: Briana B.

description:
i stayed in San Francisco in the Hilton and i find this place to be off beat. This place is one of the best diners in the area. its open a while but i ate lunch and dinner here. Its really really good place to get it. 
There is a line, but its totally worth it. the counter is good for food for a quick bite.
the varied menu is intense but worth it. 
I have good service here. no regrets.
author: Dongyi Z.

description: We chose this diner after reading the many good reviews, and it didn't disappoint. My son thought the beef macaroni & cheese was great. My mother & I got the turkey & bacon melts which were the best I've had. All the portions are very large and the prices reasonable. Definitely recommend!
author: Shell R.

description: Excellent food. Good service. Really crowded like mast good diners are. I will eat here on my next stay to San Fran.
author: N P.

description:
Dear Pinecrest Cooks,

When you call me a "pinche Chinito" I know what it means. Especially when you say it twice and right in front of me.

When I told the waitress she said she was Russian and didn't know what it meant and when I told her, she said 'oh, they call each other that sometimes.' 

I regret that I paid the bill at all.
author: Peter C.

description:
Mediocre food and service not worth the charged prices.

Stepped in for a late breakfast.  Was acknowledged immediately and allowed to select a seat anywhere as the facility was half full.  Perused through the menu and was hoping to be offered water at the least as I browsed.  I browsed  for 15 minutes and wasn't tended to again until I held the menu down on the table and launched my hand in the air.  The waitress tending to me that afternoon was too busy chatting-up a storm with the fellow diner or prospective love-interest at the counter at the other side of the restaurant. 

I placed my order and it was smooth from there...until my food arrived.  At a price tag of about $10+ (without tax and tip), the mediocre veggie omelet with extra $ for spinach is NOT worth the money.  It tasted like something I'd make myself when I'm dog-tired at 12am in my home kitchen.  Even then, I think I'd do a bit better than their product.  

As I ate, NOT ONCE did the waitress bother to come back and check-in.  Unless its a fast-food restaurant or you're ordering take-out, the idea of  dining-in, anywhere, is to receive customer service and additional courtesy.  The only additional attention I received was for the check, 1/3 of the way into my meal; before I was done or requested it.  How about asking: 'How's the food?' or 'Is there else I can get you?' 

Not returning for sure.
author: Honest J.

description:
A few of my friends and I came here for lunch after we finished checking out a showcase at the conference in HIlton. The place was pretty packed when we stepped in, but they seated us pretty quickly in the back corner next to the kitchen. It was a hard to get our waitress's attention since we were all the way in the back corner, but we managed to order fairly quickly once we've decided. I ended up getting the denver omelette, which turned out to be pretty delicious. It comes with a side of hash (YUM!) and toast (I got wheat).

Overall, service was just so-so since there was only 1 waitress taking care of the entire restaurant. The restaurant itself was fairly clean (at least the table we were sitting at), but the food is a little over-priced IMO. Perhaps that's just how it is in the City, but I would definitely go somewhere else to try new things instead!
author: Cathy W.

description:
It's hard to find any place that has vegan friendly breakfast foods.
My choices, hash browns or a veggie burger with fries.
So I ended up getting the veggie burger cause the hash browns probably wouldn't have filled me up.
It was good but too big of a portion for breakfast.
It was really crowded for breakfast and our server had to take care of like 10 tables.
author: Justine L.

description:
This is my favorite late night grub! Most of the wait staff is excellent, 99 percent success rate. The food is straight forward and good. Portions are heavy, great to blast you back to sobriety after a long night of drinking. They also serve beer, :)) 
I will always patronize this business as long as they keep the Spanish omelet.
author: Fat ass g.

description: Favourite diner in San Francisco. The Mediterranean Plate is awesome here. Great staff and service throughout.
author: Timo T.

description: Was just across the street from our hotel and had seen large lines previous days so thought it'd be a good place to try. We went around 8:40am and missed the line. It's very cramped inside, I couldn't imagine bringing in a larger group. I wasn't impressed by the food, eggs were good but I've had better hash browns and pancakes around town.
author: Hal H.

description: Really delicious food and excellent service,  the only negative aspect was the price, but else it was really good!
author: Patrick H.

description:
No frills diner with average food.  Prices are decent along with good menu choices.
24 hour service is a huge plus.

Would return if I was in the area.
author: John A.

description:
The Pinecrest was fabulous for the four of us.  We recommend the vanilla shakes and fries for a late night snack.  For breakfast you can't beat the eggs.  We sat at the counter and had a ball.  The cooks were poetry in motion.  Great entertainment.

The only issue was the restrooms.  Oh, dear.  The steep steps leading to the downstairs restrooms were quite slippery.  There was a smell coming from both the men's and the women's restrooms. I hope they read this and clean them up for future guests.  

In the meantime, eat there, but don't use the facilities.
author: Skeeter G.

description: This place was terrible. The country fried steak was not fresh and made my stomach ache. The waffle was so soft that it tasted like it was soggy and this was before I put on the syrup. The gigs were okay and the coffee was terrible. Fast service though, which can sometimes be scary when it comes to food preparation.
author: Taylor L.

description: Quick, small diner.  Hash browns were great.  Quick seating, very efficient staff.  Enjoyed it.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: This place is no-frills, but when I tell you that their food is amazing... it is AMAZING!!! I was in SF for a conference and this place was near my hotel. We just happened upon it, but ended up going there three more times before we headed back to the east coast. The Joe's Special was easily one of the BEST breakfasts I have ever had. I am not overstating this. Simply amazing! Their hash browns were phenomenal and the coffee must've had crack in it. It was the best drip coffee I have ever had! Loved it all!!
author: Kelli J.

description: We were recommended this diner by our hotel and were very displeased with the extreme rudeness! We had a group of 9 but were still waiting on 3 people who were 5 mins away. They sat us but then immediately asked if we were going to order for the 3 people that we were waiting for, and we said "no, they are five minutes away" the guy refused this answer and told us that "this was a fast restaurant and that they must be here fast or you have to order for them and you right now" we said that they would be here in five minutes. Not even a minute later the same guy came to us and told us that "they have to be here faster!" They obviously didn't want the service of 9 people, so we left. They may have good food but they really don't want you to eat it.
author: Emma W.

description: Great SF restaurant! The food is good, not flashy but the prices are the same. Great all night place.
author: Tyrone K.

description: There was ants on our table and the service was horrible. We just got drinks and decided to leave after seeing bugs. When we asked for the check to leave, the guys was rude about just paying for the drinks. We told him the reason and he was very rude and inappropriate. He even asked us if we had ever been to a BBQ.. Weird because it's a restaurant not a BBQ.
author: Sami T.

description: service was not much friendly, works hours not like announcement, my burger was not cooked , cheddar remain like piece just cutted. any time closed after 22.00.
author: Jane C.

description:
Pinecrest Dinner
SF: Union Square
Monday January 3, 2010
Three Stars


12 a.m.
This place is open 24 hours!  My date commented that the employees here look sad.  I replied that it would suck to work the graveyard shift at a dinner serving drunken assholes for barely minimum wage. The service was not bad.  I ordered the Spaghetti with homemade Meat Sauce.  It tasted more like stew but the carbs helped soaked up all the excess alcohol in my system. I also had some hash browns which were the greatest but they got the job done.  I also tried the giant banana split sundae on another diners table which was pretty good.  Thank god this night is over.
author: Leonard L.

description: I've been coming to this place as long as I remember every time I'm in San Fran. The food is good (breakfast), the coffee always fresh and the service is great and they're friendly.  What else can you expect out of a diner?
author: Ardy G.

description: I've been walking my dog past the Pinehurst Diner for a decade now, but never went in.  Tonight, though, as I was walking by, something smelled GOOD.  I went in and simply asked for a cheeseburger and fries, and the food was PERFECT.  Just what I wanted.
author: Matt T.

description:
Another no-frills restaurant, that serves typical "diner food." Nothing really special about this place. Tourist, who stay in the area, often frequent here for breakfast. So, I've always seen this place really crowded in the mornings. The best time to go is at night, less people and the service is better. (They're always rushing in the mornings and can become very careless.) 

I personally prefer Pinecrest's food over Cafe Mason's. (They're near each other.)
Their omelet's are pretty tasty and massive! I also really liked their Mediterranean plate and the French toast is decent too.  I do not like their pancakes though...yuck!

Over-all, I ate here dozens of times and even brought my mom here for breakfast, when she visited. The food is alright, nothing special...but your hungry tummy will be satisfied. Lol.
author: Lauren H.

description: Best diner in Frisco, foods great, prices are fair, and the people working there are the friendliest you'll meet they were kind and helped me figure out what a good meal for my first time here would be and they made suggestions on how rare I should have the meet and it was absolutely delicious this diner is heaven!!!
author: Alex S.

description: The operative word here is "Diner". Not "Bistro" or even "Cafe", so set your expectations accordingly, you insufferable food snobs. Great breakfast, I like their chorizo scramble. Lunch? Phenomenal sandwiches. Great Reuben, and club, decent burger. Always have great service.
author: Joey E.

description:
I enjoyed this place, and even though they had a lot to live up to by proclaiming they are "the best breakfast in town," they have a lot going for them! My friends and I were rushing to catch our flight, so we were a bit rushed and wanted to get out of the city right away. We wanted a real breakfast and saw this place, because it was near our hotel. Long story short, I had the mushroom omelet that came with toast and hash browns. It was pretty good, especially the butter on the toast! My friend had the heuvos rancheros, and it was horrible. The only good thing about it was the sliced avocados. She saved me from ordering her awful meal.

Bottomline: They were grossly understaffed and it did not help our "trying to rush out of there." My friend only ordered coffee, but the menu says that they only give refills on coffee with a purchase of an entree. We didn't see if it worked if we told the waitress if I bought the coffee. Also, there was apparently some guy wearing a bunch of make-up (a customer) that i didn't feel like turning around for.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Came here on a weekday for breakfast at around 9:30 in the morning. The place was packed but there was one stool left at the counter. The counter seats are pretty close together and it was difficult to read the paper or do much else. Only bonus to sitting at the counter is being able to watch the food being prepared which, in my opinion  makes for a better dining experience. It took a while for someone to bring me a menu and took even longer to get some coffee.

Looking at the menu I was amused to see at the top of each page there was a notice that poached eggs were not available. A while back the Pinecrest's cook shot and killed one of the waitresses there after she gave him a hard time about making a special order of poached eggs for an attractive female customer.

I ended up having eggs and a hot link -  the hash browns were perfectly crisp and the hot link was spicy. For a greasy spoon the food wasn't too bad.
author: Bumble B.

description:
I just realized I've been here three times. All three times I've been drunk. And all three times I've ordered the spaghetti, which tells me it must have been awesome! It's an over night diner, so really, nobody can complain about service since these guys deal with drunkards like me, but I'm a classy drunk. Still, it's a 24-hour diner, they're tired, shitty people come in at these hours, yada yada. Maybe I should try it in the day time, not drunk.

And try the spaghetti!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
5 stars for eggs????  YES!

I always order my eggs over medium, and usually eat them over easy.  Not at this place.  My request for crispy bacon and crispy hash browns was actually met also.  The service was OK, on both occasions.

I went back the next morning and tried one of the omelettes.  It tasted great, but a 3egg omelette with 2lbs of hash browns was a bit much for me on that day.  

I really enjoyed watching the cooks prepare the food.  They did so casually, it was effortless.  They listened to the order once, and cooked it.  The tickets were down from the kitchen, and their memory was so good, I only saw them refer to the tickets once.
author: Randy R.

description: We were staying at the Clift Hotel this weekend and wanted to get some breakfast on Saturday morning. This place was near the hotel and seemed to have the breakfast food that we enjoy. When you walk in, you seat yourself, so we sat at the counter. The  waiter was nice and I liked that I could see our food getting made. That just helps to ease your mind about the cleanliness of a place. The food was ok. Nothing amazing. But it did satisfy us. Honestly, within the hour that we were there, the place got filled pretty quick. That's a good sign for a place like this. I think it's just convenient and a no surprise type place to eat. I had the Spanish Omelet and my husband had the Pinecrest Breakfast. We ate it all and had no complaints. I would come back here again if I was in the area.
author: Carina R.

description: A great breakfast with plenty of variety, we thought it was a little expensive but it's seems it's the norm for the USA. The portions were huge and I left the restaurant unable to breath properly due to the fact I'd eaten so much, we went there every morning while we were in San Francisco, we had no reason to change venue
author: Martin T.

description:
First of i have to comment of the previous reviews. The service is not the best, but you have to understand where the restaurant is located...it's not in the a fancy part of The City, it is directly across a fast food joint, and it crawling with homeless. I have been to Pinecrest multiple times in which homeless dine & dash so, the employees don't make any money, and did excess work.

Now the review! Pinecrest Diner is a solid place for a meal. It's nothing fancy, and nothing exciting it is just standard well made American style food. The burgers are great compared the fast food joint, the salad is fresh, the chicken is made to order, omelets choices are endless. The restaurant was recently remodeled so, it is a clean, well lit place to enjoy a meal, 24hrs a day. The staff is friendly if it's not crowded due to one is dealing with orders for everyone.

If you are looking for a solid meal that is inexpensive, fresh, and made to order you should bookmark the Pinecrest Diner for your next meal
author: Nathan M.

description:
A bit overpriced I thought. A couple of the other diners down the road are as good if not better for a slightly lower price. Also, the response time of the waiting staff was a bit poor - I grew tired of waving my hands to attract attention in the end. 

I had the footlong hot-dog which was pretty decent. But nothing special. Nothing to warrant a return.
author: Neelakantan N.

description: Waiting for my room to be done at the Westin St. Francis, I realized I had skipped lunch and wanted a quick bite.  I slipped into a counter seat at the Pinecrest Diner and was immediately taken care of.  I went simple, a half a tuna sandwich on white toast and the soup of the day: split pea.  Great!  exactly as I wanted, and very generous serving.  The tuna was terrific, not too sweet, and the soup was clearly homemade.  My seat at the counter made it easy for me to watch a lot of other food being prepped, which was entertaining.  I bet the burgers are very good.
author: Carolyn P.

description:
This place feels like a classic city diner.  It is like the Seinfeld diner just way smaller.  I had the French Toast, which was quite good.  My daughter's bacon and  potatoes were good.  They did not like their scrambled eggs.

It seemed pricey.  We spent $60 bucks on the four of us.  Juice was overpriced in my opinion.  Coffee was good.
author: Hank M.

description: GREAT DIVEY DIVE!  Hangover cures abound, usually a line, but they move people in and out like clockwork..Good grub!
author: Jeff H.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of diners so I try to avoid them, but I was craving a burger and decided to give the Pinecrest Diner a shot. I was attracted to the Pinecrest because it lacked the lacquered red booths and gimmicks typically found at American Diners. Instead, the Pinecrest has a very plain truck-stop like look/feel to it. I ordered the Mushroom Swiss burger with chili-cheese fries and I was thoroughly impressed. The burger was spectacular and piled-high with grilled mushrooms, really the best burger one could hope for. The meat was juicy and was not dry. The fries and chili-sauce were wonderful, crispy and well seasoned. I couldn't ask for more. Priced very reasonably. 

Four stars for food/service and the fifth star is for the 24 hours that they're open. Excellent.
author: John Q.

description:
I am amazed their grade is so low
People, get some breakfast and you wont be disappointed - perfect hasbrowns, light and fluffy eggs, crisp bacon, can't be beat
author: Sam A.

description: The Good: Great food and nice portions. Con: I suspect they are trying to gouge tourists but it's overpriced for what exactly they are serving (especially beverages) regardless of their location. Wait staff disappears never to be seen until it's time to pay. And there is nothing more annoying than being handed the bill while I am still eating.
author: Randy S.

description:
Pinecrest Diner proved an excellent place for our first breakfast during a recent girls' trip to San Francisco. We knew nothing about the place except for the fact that it lay in between our hotel and our desired MUNI stop. And we were hungry. Seattle has a dearth of spots the likes of Pinecrest, so we were also pleased to have a "diner" experience. 

Though it appeared people were waiting to get in, our party of four was seated in roughly five minutes. I had expected a crabby, put-upon server but our waitress was smiley and warm. The busman (he was not a "boy") was one of the most industrious individuals I have ever watched work. 

I was most pleased with my ham & egg scramble with hashbrowns...the ample portion of sourdough toast threatened to steal the show from the entree. A real surprise was my friend's tuna salad...whereas we had expected a sad plate of iceberg lettuce, the dish was a healthy bowl of chopped romaine with three dollops of tuna deliciousness. 

My only complaint: $4.25 for a large OJ seemed a bit much.

While we were dining, my cousin texted me to say that "The Pursuit of Happyness" was filmed at Pinecrest. And apparently the diner was the site of a murder over an order of eggs. Tasty, and historical.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I have come here on rare occasions since 1998. I used to love it. Not so much anymore. Looks like the management has changed at some point. Todays experience was expensive (18.95 for small orange juice, coffee, pancakes with scrambled, sausage, and bacon). The waiter was bossy and service was overall slow and inattentive. I asked for a table facing Geary, but the waiter asked me not to sit there "because it was not cleaned", or rather too far away so he would have to walk a little to serve me. I had emptied my coffee before the food came and I had put the cup out near the end of the table, but the waiter did not even check this when he came with the food (This is a must at a breakfast diner). The diner was less than half full. Pancakes: below average, Scrambled eggs: good, bacon: good. Coffee: fair. Service: I will never return to this place again.
author: William K.

description:
Thank  you Pinecrest Diner for saving me from a potential hangover!

After drinking at the Alkaline Trio show, closing down the bar around the corner, our hotels concierge suggested this place.
So I take it they are open 24 hours since it must have been at least 2 in the morining.
I gobbled down a tasty Ruben sandwich with fries to help soak up some of the random booze in my system.

Still woke up with a bit of a headache but things could have been a lot worse.
author: Noel J.

description:
food was good
big portions
I got the spanish omlette

the yelp deal (2 entries, get an appetizer) they wouldn't fulfill.  Lame.

near the end of the meal, they started cleaning the bathroom dungeon and smelled so bad we all had to stop eating.  You know it's bad when you have to run outside and the tenderloin air is "fresh".

guess it's all relative.  wouldn't mind going back, also wouldn't mind never going back.
author: Van W.

description: Diner food with a mix of local and tourist diners. Nothing really stood out. I'd eat here again, but there are probably better options nearby that I'd try first.
author: David D.

description: Thanks yelpers - the hash browns and the sourdough toast were as good as the reviews say!  And as I mentioned in my last review, if your table is not obnoxious, then the service is quick.  I was at a well-behaved table this time so the service was great.
author: Chris L.

description: The cob salad and California Mac 'n cheese was amazing. We sat at the counter and watched the line chef work his magic!
author: Jim H.

description: I used to come here for breakfast. Now I go to Lori's across the street. Unfriendly staff. Never get the breakfast order right. Not clean looking.
author: Mark G.

description:
Maybe 2.5, but I can't quite justify a 3 star rating.  We knew it was risky to wander into a diner without checking Yelp first, but we were hungry and looking for a place that wouldn't break the bank, so we ended up trying Pinecrest.  I wish we had gone somewhere else.

The diner looks nice (they finished a remodeling).  When we walked in, we were the only customers in the place, but it got busy right afterwards.  This confused our poor waiter and the cooks.  We ordered the split pea soup, which was delivered promptly and was quite good.  Then we waited forever for a salad and hamburger.  We could see that the cook was confused by the orders (he didn't speak or read English apparently, so someone else had to tell him what was going on).  

The hamburger was overcooked and not very big for the price, and they use processed swiss cheese instead of the real thing.  The fries were cooked fine, but unseasoned.  The salad arrived after the burger, and we never did get the onion rings (but they didn't appear on the bill, so I guess the waiter missed it when ordering).

It wasn't a horrible meal, but it wasn't a good one, either.  I'm not expecting gourmet dining, but a diner should produce a better burger and be able to handle serving 4 or 5 tables at the same time.  Sorry, Pinecrest, but we won't be returning (unless it's just for that soup).
author: Areena M.

description: Although the prices are somewhat prices, I thought my meal tasted fantastic.  also, our server was very attentive and nice. She sounded like she was from Russia.  The seating seems kinda cramped, but overall, I would go back and eat here in a heartbeat.
author: James C.

description: This breakfast was delicious! I had an omelette and it was very good. Yummy local sourdough bread, non-greasy hash browns, strong and flavorful coffee! Even on Valentine's Day, it wasn't too busy, but space is most definitely limited in this little diner.
author: Nikki H.

description:
For all the years I've lived in SF, I've always passed by this diner...never once have I stepped in until last Sunday....

Only because my "god brother" was visiting and he was in downtown...he suggested to meet there....oy...I said....

3 stars for letting us have coffee/tea for an hour's worth of chatting...it was nice...not as sticky as I imagined....
author: Barb L.

description:
Wednesday, 10:00PM.

Quickie:
+Fast turnaround

Suggestions:
*Local or sustainable products please!
*Cleaner feel to the place

And then...?
Typical diner.

**********
Stuffed my face in:
1. Pinecrest omelette
     - Banal dish

2. Chocolate pancakes
     - Didn't disperse the chocolate well
author: Chuck N.

description: During the holidays it is hard to find restaurants without a line or wait. We went into this place thinking the food would be terrible however it was great. My husband ordered the Joe's special and loved every bite.The only problem is the restaurants appearance. It can use some renovating.
author: Keya M.

description:
If you downtown in the middle of the night and hungry, check this place out. The food is not bad and it's a little bit of a greasy spoon diner. 

FOOD: 
* Burger - a little small for the price that I paid, but it came with fries, they were a little greasy. 
* Mushroom Omelette - was tasty with a lot of veggies! YUM 
* Country Fried Steak - over cooked a bit and dry. The gravy was so so. 

Space: 
Classic diner 

Service: 
Nothing stood out, they don't really talk much. Straight forward service. 

Check this place out if there's nothing else open and you want diner food.
author: Fried Rice B.

description: Hum drum Clam Chowder. Decent Spaghetti Bolognese, but super greasy. Their breakfast may be good, but not their dinner.
author: Michael S.

description: I would not recommended going here to anyone. The food was ok, through the serves was horrible. First it took forever to get served, and even more time to get food. Second, when it was time to get the bill my friends and I ask to slipt the bill. To this the manager who ended up serving us after a few other waiter, got pissed and was complaining about spilting the check! While he was going back and forth our table talking about it doing this simple act and making my friends very uncomfortable. Then finally the most atrocious act was  when he did split the check for us, and we went up to pay for it. One of my friend paid with her card her part of the $76 check (which by the way was Hella a lot by the way for each meal costing about 12 each). But anyway after this she paid $17.70 for a burger and coke. My friend friends and I paid $80 for the rest, and the manager took the $80 and gave back $4. So if response I told him that he took to much money and he should give us back $17.70. And this asshole told us to go away. Words can not express how angery and cheated I feel. I will never go back to place, and for those who want to go to place I would say tread lightly for this places tries to steal your money for nothing but shitting servers.
author: M S.

description: On a block with 4 diners, this one comes in 3rd place. Staff is friendly and quick, place is not that big for major delays. Food is average, but place is dingy.
author: Maurice B.

description:
This place is lackluster at best. With all the awesome restaurants in the Union Square area, I am so disappointed that we wasted our time, money and taste buds at this joint. 

Before coming to Pinecrest we tried Dotties True Blue Cafe and Taylor Street Coffee House which both had lines out the door. We were starving and relived to find there was no wait here for mid morning Sunday brunch. We were seated fairly quickly in the back of the restaurant. First impression, the place had a bit of a funk. But i was so hungry I held my nose and ordered my food.

I tired to get a basic breakfast sandwich with egg, cheese and turkey bacon. The sandwiches listed on the menu come as "scrambles" so I had to special order my request. Yes, the portions are huge, but I'd rather a smaller plate of better quality food. My sandwich came with two eggs on a large hoaggie roll rather than a hard round roll. They use what I call "plastic cheese," that McDonalds style overprocessed cheddar instead of the real stuff. My turkey bacon was hard and overcooked. The hasbrowns were plentiful but flavor-less. The only saving grace was the pancake, luckily those are hard to mess up. 

$43 for thee people (no coffie, juice or tea) for a sub-par diner breakfast is rediculous. Taylor Street Coffee Shop and Honey Honey are a few bocks away and offer much better quality and value food.
author: Ambur F.

description: Down home cooking. Steak and eggs, omelette home fries, hash browns, OM NOM NOM oh so good. Especially for a late night and after drinking. Kind of a sketchy area but well worth the money and portions you get.
author: Maria B.

description: Typical diner fare. Seat yourself. Service was prompt and friendly. Got a Cobb salad ~$13 and some chicken dish ~$15. They forgot to bring the dinner roll but it was fine because neither of us finished our meal. There was some weird message at the bottom of the menu that said you had to spend at least $7. Didn't run in to that but just thought it was weird.
author: Jay O.

description: Wouldn't go back here.  Got eggs, bacon, hash browns and toast.  Pretty basic but still no good.  It was the hash browns.  They were so oily - and like rancid oil. And before ordering I had asked about the corned beef hash - apparently it's canned, not fresh.  Why even offer it on the menu of you don't make it fresh?  The servers were friendly, but still...  There are better diners.  Skip this spot.
author: Stephanie J.

description: Hash browns are great the toast is fine but my chx fried steak is pretty bad. It taste horrible
author: Thomas P.

description: This place is severly underrated. After waiting in line at mama's for 2 hours for mediocre food, I realized why I love Pinecrest Diner so much. Just went for my second time and yet again it didn't dissapoint. Love the old school diner feel, the staff is always super friendly and the food is amazeballs. Can't go wrong with the chicken fried steak & eggs! Every time I visit SF I will make it a point to go to Pinecrest for breakfast!
author: Brittany G.

description: Yes. Just yes. Diner food served fast and hot. It's not gourmet. It's a diner. Waitstaff are not terribly friendly--but you brought me what I wanted, fast and well-cooked.
author: Lydia K.

description: The breakfasts here are drenched in so much oil and butter, so don't come here if you are looking for a healthier option
author: Darren D.

description: Food came out within like 5 minutes after we ordered. Service was great and the establish,net was clean. Bathrooms were not so clean though. Food and service great though.
author: John B.

description: I was craving for a quick and light dinner, and the concierge at Hotel Monaco sent me here. I ordered a beef and vegetable soup. The bowl looked dirty and there was a couple little fruit flies in them. Maaaybe I would've dismissed it if it was made with organic veggies, but it wasn't.
author: Tanya H.

description: Was there for a quick meal at 4AM, the food was decent and service friendly. Nothing memorable, but a nice spot to grab something quick when it's very late in the night.
author: Julien N.

description:
This is a diner, not fine dining, and a really good diner.

We needed a quick meal close to our hotel so we decided to check out the Pinecrest. The service was fast and friendly and the food was hot and tasty. Fantastic Reuben!

We enjoyed this spot more than many of the fancier and more expensive restaurants we visited around Union Square.
author: John B.

description:
According to legend, a chef killed a waiter there over an argument about Poached eggs, and now they don't serve that dish. They actually indicate that on the menu. The story makes me laugh every time. Nevertheless, the Pinecrest Diner is a no non-sense hole-in-the-wall diner that serves breakfast 24/7. I've been to this place at 2am and there are still a few tables being taken up. People here are nice and friendly and you can have a good time just watching the passersby. I usually go for the eggs and ham, and they do serve a generous slice of ham. In the afternoons, I go for the cheeseburgers with fries. They don't mess them up here! 

Lastly, the restroom is two floors under the restaurant; go at your own risk.
author: William H.

description:
This place definitely did its job being a quick place to eat before heading back to South Bay.  I went to a wedding and stayed at Sir Francis Drake and the next Sunday morning wanted a place in walking distance. 

There are tons of places to eat near Union Square.  We wanted to check out Dottie's True Blue Cafe with the 1k plus high reviews but of course at close to noon the place was PACKED.  We didn't want to wait so we chose this place. 

Their was no wait for Pinecrest Diner but it was crackin with people so that was a good sign. 

I ordered 
- Pinecrest Omelette with wheat toast and instead of hash browns got fruits which was honey dew and strawberries cut up cute

I didn't finish the breakfast but on the way in the homeless guy out front said I know you probably will finish the food because they always do but if you don't I'll take it.  I made sure to give my food to the homeless guy. ;) 

Its pretty cool that this place is opened pretty late for the after club spot.  Its not too far from Slide and Ruby Skye.  Its a better alternative than Jack n a Box and dare I say Pizza by the Slice which is by every corner in SF! 
-
author: Anya R.

description:
It's a greasy spoon.  But if it's a greasy spoon you're after, you're gonna like it!  

We were staying just up the block and wandered in one mid-morning for a leisurely late breakfast.  The place was packed at ~10am, but we only waited a couple of minutes for a booth.  The servers are working HARD - management has them understaffed.  This didn't affect our table, but several other booths looked annoyed by their wait.  

I went with a Denver omelet with swiss, hashbrowns and whole wheat toast.  Loved it!  Have to concur with an earlier reviewer that the hash browns are excellent (read: crispy and slathered in butter/grease) and my omelet completely hit the spot.  Partner had the Spanish omelet and raved about it - hidden under salsa with half an avocado and a squirt of sour cream.  Myself, I found it rather bland.  Food came up quickly.  You pay at the counter.  Prices were tourist-level.  

...and we went back the next day.  I know, my poor liver!  But it was that good...  Me, Denver again but with cheddar, him Spanish.  Mine was better the first time, his the second.  We camped out at the bar this time and watched the kitchen work.  I don't know that they'd pass a snap health inspection, but hey, it's a diner, I guess I'm willing to relax my standards.
author: Andy W.

description: I was wondering why this place was packed for breakfast on a weekday, so I tried it.  I figured it out...they do breakfast right, and they make the best hash browns anywhere.
author: Reid F.

description:
We ended up at Pinecrest Diner after our impatience (and hunger) took over while waiting for a table at Dottie's about a block away.

The diner was busy but we were able to get a booth right away. Our waitress was very friendly and helpful. I ordered the Pinecrest omelet and my boyfriend ordered the Greek omelet. Our food arrived very quickly. My omelet was delicious and he loved his as well. I have to admit it was so much tastier than I was anticipating. I would definitely try Pinecrest again in the future.
author: Jo C.

description:
Obviously this is not a fancy place for dining but god I love their food. Some of their sandwiches are better than ones you get in nicer restaurants. I absolutely LOVE their omelets, portions are huge and the ingredients are all fresh. I guess one thing I really like about Pinecrest is they use really fresh ingredients which is not a norm for diners. My usual dish here is the chicken pesto, I can only eat half of it on a good day as it is huge but every time the chicken breast has been juicy and full of flavor, grilled to perfection. For the first time we tried the spaghetti, and as another yelper mentioned it was pretty darn good. The sauce is pretty meaty with mushrooms and doesn't taste like it was canned/acidic. Awesome salads too! 
I give it 5 stars only for food, obviously you can't expect the best service or ambiance but for a diner it deserves all the stars.
author: Shell S.

description:
Took a random stab at this place. Was cruising with a friend, feeling like a zombie due to the rough night before, and we were looking for something to hold us over. We stopped here because it was packed and the food looked legit.

We ordered a bowl of chili to start. I had the Hawaiian breakfast deal which consisted of eggs, hash brown, toast, ham with pineapple and cherry on top. Wait a sec: ham, pineapples, cherries, scrambled eggs, chili all together? Did I forget that I was in SF and not Hawaii? I should've just asked for spam too. 

The portions here were very generous. The food was pretty decent for morning breakfast. Too bad I didn't have a real appetite so I was not able to take down too much of my food. Our waitress was really nice and took care of us. The place was continuously packed throughout my time there. 

Going to the bathroom was like diving into the depths of hell. Many steps downwards, narrow stairways, and short ceilings. Be careful, follow the signs, and I hope you are quite sober or you may never be coming back up. 

And a last note, orange juice is non-refillable.
author: Smitcha B.

description: I was in town for the weekend and just happened to walk by this place.  The food was good but it was definitely not anything special but the service was awesome!  It's it's a very classic diner and was a good choice for some quick breakfast!
author: Dan M.

description: When we saw the $12 price for a bowl of oatmeal at our hotel, my wife and I strolled around the neighborhood and wandered into Pinecrest.  Sitting at the counter, we enjoyed watching the choreography of the person working the grill, the person cranking out omelets, and the wait staff doing things like prepping the toast and doing final plating.  It was great to see how the entire staff worked together on a busy Sunday morning.  The food was just what I was looking for - filling and appropriately greasy and salty in the right places.  Not the finest dining experience I've had, but a welcome find in this neighborhood.
author: John K.

description: The food is here is just okay nothing exceptional, it's pretty standard for what you would expect to find in a classic American diner. The fact that it's open 24/7 is what makes it awesome and a decent option for late night drunchies. I got the chicken fried steak served with hash browns after barhopping around 3am (yeah...I'm a fatass). I'm not sure if I would choose to come here during regular hours as the food didn't impress me too much and service was slow.
author: Kevin N.

description: Best tasting diner food at 3am in the morning!! I go their so often, they know my usual.. Bacon & Swiss omelette, hold the hash browns
author: Shai W.

description:
The Spanish Omelette here is great. Unlike other places (Subway), they do not skimp on avocado here and will give you your money's worth! 

Pros:
-Great food, consistent quality. I've never been disappointed in the 10+ times I've been- whether it was 8am, 3pm or whatever
-Good service
-Open 24 hours. You can literally have it whenever you want it

Cons:
-It sounds like it'd be a great after club idea (near Ruby Skye, Slide) but everyone is thinking the same thing so good luck getting a table
author: Carolyn A.

description:
We hadn't eaten dinner before the theater and we sort of jumped into the 
Pinecrest after the show let out, it was active, warm and open. 

It's an old fashioned, good food diner, great service, good coffee and plenty of it. My son's patty melt was perfect and don't let the first bites of the Cincinnati Chili fool you, it seems ordinary at first but builds into one of the great spaghetti/chili dishes on this coast. 

Pinecrest is now a must do after the show now!
author: Deborah P.

description:
I just moved away from the Tendernob, but while living in the area, Pinecrest was in my Fav 5 of Saturday morning breakfast stops. I'd guesstimate I've been 20 times?

Better than average versions of standards, nice people, good prices and portions...nothing fancy, but a consistent experience, which is about all I want at 9am.

I'd go again for sure, if I were in the area.
author: Greg J.

description: Service very fast and efficient- food very good. Had 2 different omelettes-2 days. I think it is deserves higher than typical 3 stars. Good hot coffee-also appreciated they offer delicious fresh fruit substitute for hash browns- nice!!
author: Deborah S.

description: Very popular place, and for good reason! Went for breakfast around 9AM and the place was packed. Once we got seated we all ordered coffee which I was very pleased with because it was really strong. I ordered the Bay Shrimp omelette with sourdough toast and it was spectacular! At our table we also had an Italian omelette (with Italian sausage!), a Pinecrest omelette (everything you could want in an omelette), and the Pinecrest special (amazing pancakes!) Let me just say that although it seems unimportant, this diner had the best maple syrup we've ever had! Truly a wonderful meal, even if the restaurant itself is rather small. The best breakfast in San Francisco!
author: Kristen D.

description: I would have given 5 stars if the review were based on the food only.  The service was a bit slow, but friendly.  We had pesto chicken sandwich, Mac and cheese, and the foot long hot dog.  Even though we were stuffed, we managed to shove a banana split down our throats.  Awesome.
author: Aaron B.

description:
I can eat breakfast food for any meal. Enter, Pinecrest Diner. 

In a random trip to SF, my boyfriend and I Yelped places that served waffles. After being super unsuccessful, we found Pinecrest, a 24-hour diner. Think, Pulp Fiction setting. (well, that's how I felt hunny bunny). It feels like the kind of place where you feel at home when you walk in. We were welcomed in and told to sit anywhere we like. 

I crave waffles all the time, so when I read it on the outside menu I was completely hooked. Our server/cashier was super friendly, even late at night. The booths are wide and plentiful so there's plenty of room to spread out and enjoy your meal. Prices are super cheap for what you get, too! I got a big waffle, eggs, bacon and OJ for my late night snack and my bf got a big plate of chicken nachos. OMG, heaveeeeennnnn. 

So for all you sexy drunkies in SF, crawl over to Geary St. and get your food on!
author: Steph C.

description: The breakfast was hot and plentiful. Hubby had the Greek Omelette and I had the Country Fried Steak and eggs. Our waiter was great and they topped off my coffee with no prompting. Also, much more affordable than other places in the area for breakfast.
author: Alfonsina S.

description: I will eat breakfast here every time I come to The city. Good, honest, yummy dinner food. Quick and efficient. Great way to start the day!
author: Torry H.

description: Upgrading to 4 stars because I ordered their fried chicken this time and was super impressed by how delicious it was! For $14 you get 4 pieces and fries. I think it is one of the best fried chicken in SF! My husband had the super nachos which also wowed him. I'm constantly surprised by this place. I'm now a regular.
author: Vol T.

description:
This place was convenient.  The greasy food was decent, but then again I didn't care much about anything that evening.  It was pretty busy in the wee morning hours.  I just wish they'd had more help to better attend to their patronage.  One server and one cook is not enough!

Again it's great because it's open 24/7, but I've had better.
author: Gabriel C.

description: Yummy Greek patty melt. 24 hour diner food. Great for when you're out late. Friendly service.
author: Tiffany B.

description:
My father has never lived in San Francisco, yet I eat dinner with him every Wednesday night, and we often come to Pinecrest Diner.  

No, he's not some guy with too much money on his hands and a personal jet, but he has come out of retirement to work part time in a city 400 miles from home in order to help out a friend and former colleague.  And although I work a 9-to-5 in Berkeley and do pub trivia every Wednesday, we're always able to squeeze in a respectable dinner in between the closing bell and the general-knowledge round.

It's always nice to have a 24-hour place near Union Square (I would say the Tenderloin, which might be technically true, but I don't want to scare you), and while this place could be an absolutely disgusting dive and still do well, it's actually really nicely appointed and clean.  The service is usually slow, but that's because one person is working the entire restaurant plus the cash register.  I can also do without the TVs, but they kind of fade into the background, especially if you're seated facing away from the front door.

The menu is OK.  Aside from breakfast, there are only a few vegetarian options, but again, it's better than you expect it to be.  The salads in particular are well proportioned, and the Italian dressing tastes good (although it's sometimes kind of lumpy).

I think the booths are moleskin, which used to bother me until I learned that moleskin isn't made from moles' skin anymore, but there might be some leather as well, and that bothers me in a very mild way, like a baby crying in a room four doors down the hall.

When you're here, be sure to stand underneath the awning--unless it's raining.  See, it's a purely decorative awning; there's a custom-cut hole in the top to allow a second-floor fire-escape ladder to be lowered to the sidewalk.  I don't think I've ever seen anything like that before.

UPDATE:  4/28/11
==============

I'm knocking Pinecrest Diner down a star because its restrooms are completely wheelchair inaccessible.  They're clean, and they're really fun to find, and they have black toilets (!), but they still discriminate against wheelchair users.
author: John S.

description: Great breakfast food, cool "old school diner atmosphere"!  I was a party of 1 on a brisk San Francisco weekday morning, crossing the street from my hotel, The Hotel Diva, to get a quick breakfast.  This was my first time ever in San Francisco and my expectations for food were very high!  Since it was just me, I was told I had to sit at the counter.  I sat there, watched my food being cooked...hash browns with several douses of clarified butter on them to get that crunchy consistency, a perfectly cooked omelet and a piping cup of hot coffee in a dented ceramic cup; the dented ceramic cup reminded me of having a cup of coffee at my grandmother's house.
author: Timothy S.

description: We put the order and 5 min later they bring it.....Wow. but the price is high. What ever happened to the 4.99 specials.  But over all the food was good and the portions were big. COME HUNGRY!!!!!!!!
author: Mike M.

description: So good! That's all I want to say. Efficient service, tasty food, nostalgic ambience, good prices. Heart of union square. What more do you need?
author: Indian G.

description: Eggs were fab. Good diner food!
author: Courtney T.

description:
Service was fast and food is great! Ordered the pine crest special and loved it! Their hash browns are cooked perfectly as well as their sausage and bacon!

Yum!
author: Lauren W.

description: The french toast and coffee were to die for. Will be back tomorrow before leaving for sure.
author: The Real F.

description:
This honestly is one of my favorite places for breakfast in the area and I generally pop in for breakfast at least once or twice a month.

Also, when I walk down Powell and past the long queue at Sears, I generally try to encourage a few to give up the wait and go to Pinecrest instead.

Why do i like it?

1.  They have American cheese.  It's really the only processed food that I like and I resent the places that are too refined to have it as an option on the menu.  Tastes really good with eggs.  Put it on your menu!

2.  Service is quick

3.  Food is really fresh and they use fresh quality ingredients 

Like everything else, their prices have increased.  An omelette (no coffee or juice) plus a decent tip is $13.  On the steep side for a diner breakfast, but alas it's San Francisco.
author: Amy Z.

description: The breakfast is delicious.   The portions are the right size...not too big and not too small.  The staff is very friendly  and efficient.
author: Manny A.

description:
We walked around Union Square looking for a restaurant with prices on the cheaper side.  There were many restaurants charging on the higher side some people can't afford.  We found Pinecrest at the corner.

Don't let the 1950s exteriors and interiors fool you.  The food was standard diner food.  I ordered the breakfast bacon, scrambled eggs, hash browns, and toast.  She ordered the pastrami sandwich.  Service was standard diner service.  The wait for our food was short.  I come back the next time we're at Union Square and want to eat lower price food.

One downside was the diner got really warm.  It's rare San Francisco reaches the 80 degree range.  The unseasonable warm temperatures made the diner stuffy.
author: Raymond M.

description:
"We Serve the Best Breakfast in San Francisco!" - that is what this place touts. So on a recent visit and being a big fan of breakfast, of course, we had to go try it out. Unfortunately, they weren't able to represent. 

Firstly, we walk in and it seemed like there was one server, one busboy and a bunch of people in the kitchen. We were told to sit wherever there was a seat. Luckily, a booth was open. I can't even imagine the chaos this system would cause during a busy breakfast or lunch rush. 

The food was ok, somewhat on the greasy side. Considering it was nothing very special, I thought it was too pricey. We spent about $50 for breakfast plates and orange juice for two!!! 

Also, here's a tip I wish I had known - the bathroom is downstairs, way, way downstairs. Bring a friend with you!
author: AP S.

description: Decent Cheeseburger meal, open late night on Geary. Kinda pricey, but they advertise their beef to be all natural. I remember service being a bit short and neglectful for a place that wasn't busy at the late hour.
author: Briget P.

description: This place is awesome!! The service is absolutely fantastic, the food is delicious and fresh, and they have great coffee. If you're looking for a good old fashioned diner style breakfast in the Union Square area, this is the place to go! It's a small and cozy kind of place, and the kitchen area is right in view of the customers. All of the staff is super attentive and friendly. This is the kind of place that's hard not to visit on a daily basis!
author: Melissa M.

description: This place is GREAT. Everytime we have come here the food is soo good! The BLT is delicious. It is not greasy, the bacon is well made and the fries are wonderful! The seats are comfortable and the staff is really nice. This is definitely one of our favorite sandwich places. Great fresh made to order food, and the kitchen is right before your eyes. LOVE IT!!!
author: Nauti S.

description: My food was amazing. It was delicious, but my boyfriend found a hair deep in his food that most definitely wasn't mine. I doubt that happens often but the waiter tried to tell him he was lying. So I thought that was weird but he gave him a discount and that was very good of them.
author: Lauren H.

description: Breakfast was great . I ordered huevos rancheros . It was tasty and light . The plate was very full !!!! I would order again . It was filling without being too heavy. Service was a little slow ... But they were very busy !
author: Sheryl G.

description: I ordered the Reuben Sandwich, phenomenal. I wish they delivered. I would order lunch from here. I recommend this place to anyone. The history is eerie, but still a feeling of curiosity. Bring a friend or two.
author: Carlos H.

description: The food is okay... And one thing that caught my attention are the servers... One of the server did not wash his hands after handling cash and bussing tables... Then he took a bread, put a butter and put it in the toaster without washing hands...
author: Ryan F.

description: Good food and a fun atmosphere. Reasonable prices for the large portions. It's a great tourist attraction if you wanna sit in an American style breakfast place.
author: Asaf R.

description:
Not wanting to spend forever finding something to eat, a friend and I stopped in at the Pinecrest Diner to grab something quick and easy to eat one night during our to trip to San Francisco and although the restaurant definitely has a nice old school diner feel, the food is a bit lacking.

Not being in the mood for breakfast food, I decided to go with the reuben sandwich and fries as an alternative and while it wasn't the worst sandwich I have ever had, it definitely wasn't the best either. About half way through the meal, I began to wish I would have just gone with breakfast food like my friend did because her meal looked ten times better than mine.

Other than the food, my only real complaint is the bathrooms are located down a two flights of super slippery stairs in the basement of the building which seemed a little awkward and annoying. The service was fine, and the restaurant was clean enough. Overall, this is a pretty average spot in an area which is packed full of betting dining options.
author: Jeremy O.

description: Great diner. Clean, fast. Terrific service. Varied and complete menu. We had breakfast. Huevos rancheros with four fresh, nearly hand made tortillas and an abundant omelette. All very good, hot, fresh. Great price. Dinner looked like a good option for people on a budget.
author: Julie F.

description:
Had to drive to Fremont to see some potential clients about an upcoming shoot.
We wound up staying overnight and decided to drive into the city for a couple of hours before heading back home to Smogville.

Of course, the wife wanted to go to Macy's at Union Square, so we finally found a parking space and walked until we stumbled upon Pinecrest Cafe, when we realized we were hungry.

The lone asian woman working the front - was also the only one working the back...so she had her hands full with all the business-like people that had ducked inside to grab some lunch.

After a short wait, we ordered our food and got our drinks.
the burgers were actually quite good for a diner...though it did seem a bit pricey - but hey - it's San Francisco.  At least the seasalted air is free!
author: A T.

description: This is one of the rare 24 hour restaurants in the SF area. And it's a block from Union Square, so if you're staying around the area and hungry at a weird hour, this is the place to go. I actually came from breakfast, sat at the counter and had the hash and eggs with sourdough toast. It was perfect. The hash was cooked til it got that nice crust (the proper way to cook hash), eggs were perfect sunny side up, and my coffee cup was constantly refilled. I was so grateful for that -- suffering from a caffeine deficit after traveling on the redeye the previous night. There was no wait even though the restaurant was full. The staff operate like a well-oiled machine and were so friendly. Eat slow, don't feel rushed, and enjoy the atmosphere. It's a diner, the kind I really like, and I am going to go again.
author: Presh C.

description:
Food 4*
Location 4*
Ambiance 3*
Service 3*
Prices 2*

Good diner fare, but overpriced. No wait when we arrived (9am) and tables seemed to turn over fairly quickly. Portions were generous. OJ was fresh, and coffee was okay. Service was quick, but I was turned off when the waiter turned to us to take the order of the table right beside us (the tables are tight and his backside was facing us as we were eating). We did have to ask for coffee refills, but overall a true diner experience.
author: Karen C.

description:
A solid three stars. 

Friendly staff, competent cook, filling starchy food that lacks pizazz (if you want pizazz, add tabasco), and prices befitting of this joint's real estate. 

I won't be rushing back, but I imagine this place would look pretty great for someone at the tail end of an all night bender.
author: Siobhán K C.

description: Terrible service. Came in with my girlfriend after checking out of our hotel that was nearby. The place was busy so we figured it couldn't be too terrible. We were wrong. The service was terrible, waited a long time for our food to arrive, the cups were dirty, over priced for canned corned beef hash, chicken fried steak was hard as a rock. NEVER coming back here. 30 dollars for below average food.
author: Kaye P.

description:
After a disappointing experience at my swanky hotel bar, I hoofed it down the street to find something to eat. Mainly, I was in search of a burger and fries.

I came across the Pinecrest and quickly whipped out my Yelp (Lori's is also across the street, so I was looking to see which had more stars. Dead tie.)

It's everything you want a diner to be. Counter seats, fast service, short order cook just outside of arm's reach from the counter.  

I ordered the mushroom & swiss burger (medium) with a side of fries. Damn..... that hit the spot. I'd been traveling that day and I was starving. It was well cooked and flavorful.

I know it's a diner, but I am surprised to see it get 3 stars. What's a 5 star diner?
author: Harry F.

description: We had breakfast twice and a light dinner once and all three of us we happy with everything we ordered, good prices, fast and friendly service. It was close to our hotel, comparable food and 1/3 the price.
author: Maryna B.

description: There was a live bug in my burger. I told the water to come and the bug jumped on my hand. Fortunately I didn't start eating it yet. The most confusion part was that instead of hearing sorry the waiter took the bug, came back and asked if I want to eat it or not. Can't say about food taste,  haven't tried it.
author: Hugh M.

description: One of my favorite diners ever.   I usually get the spicy chicken sandwich with fries and a side of ranch.  The lady always remembers me and she is just the nicest person ever.  The fries are the best here, and the sandwiches are bomb as well.  On top of that there's just a great atmosphere inside, very classic diner ambience.  Great for lone dining, or to get a booth with some friends.  I love this place.
author: Drew B.

description: Great diner food and friendly service. Came in after a long day of sightseeing. Yummy comfort food of breakfast for dinner was the perfect choice. Huge servings and some gluten free options.
author: Beth K.

description: If you like greasy, flavorless food along with slow and unattentive service then this is definitely the place for you. We had breakfast here a few days ago.  Once seated, it took more than 15 minutes just to get our menus, another 30 minutes to get our order while the people who were seated after us received their food. My son's mushroom and sausage omelette was awful. The rubbery mushrooms were obviously dumped out of a can. My eggs and hashbrown were ok.  My husbands corned beef hash not as good as many other places. Very disappointed.
author: Happy S.

description: Had a great breakfast, pinecrest special with French toast. The food was great French toast was not soggy, was actually crispy. Eggs cooked to order. Bacon was crispy. Walked in and greeted right away. Sat down pretty quickly.
author: Robert L.

description: They're open 24 hours! This is a great little diner right on the corner of Geary. The wait staff is super efficient and super nice.
author: Courtney F.

description:
Ahhhh, Pine Crest...what can I say about you? Well, one of your charms is that, as Jeff B said in his review, you're not a "faux diner". No, you are definitely hard-core. I've visited you at all hours of the day and night and your ambiance is always the same: Grim, gritty, greasy.

But that's okay, because you don't pretend to be anything else. You sling that solid diner grub onto the plate with no apologies. Caramelized onions on my burger? HA! I know better than to ask. Complain that I have to go into a scary dungeon maze to reach the bathroom from hell? I wouldn't dare.

I will do as I did today and sit quietly and meekly at the counter and wait the 6 short minutes for my BLT, piled high with bacon that is the perfect combination of crispy and chewy, and my freshly-fried fries that are crisp on the outside and creamy on the inside.

Oh, and while I'm waiting, I'll pretend I can't see that guy in the back scraping a greasy mess off the grill pan. What I don't know can't hurt me.
author: Valeria R.

description: They got the order wrong. Food was mediocre. They rushed us out of the door and no one said a single sorry or thank you.
author: Ana D.

description:
They don't have a list... when they're crowded you just sort of form a civilized line and wait for them to move you to a table. 

Service isn't very good, but it was just a regular diner. IT'S JUST A REGULAR DINER. Don't try and substitute anything- they won't do it.

Instead, man up, walk a couple blocks in any direction and find a better place. You're in San Fran- here is no excuse for mediocre food.
author: Jane H.

description: This place Was ok and just that.  Food was cookie cut take out of the freezer throw in fryer stuff in a city with such great food this place needs to step up their game!
author: Jeffrey M.

description: Basic diner breakfast..we left full and ready for the day. Bacon and eggs French toast pretty average.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
While in San Francisco getting my car worked on at a specialty repair shop, I went walking to find a place to eat. I happened upon the Pinecrest Diner and decided to give it a try. I am really glad I did! The service was fast and friendly, the counter was clean. It was one of those rare days in SF when it was warm, so sitting at the counter was a little toasty, but since it's usually cold in SF, I find that to be a good thing. 

I ordered the pastrami sandwich and fries. I forgot to mention that I wanted cheddar cheese on my sandwich, and the owner/manager? took it back and added my cheese no problem. The pastrami was first-rate in fact some of the best I have ever tasted and the fries were done to perfection. 

So why am I giving this place five stars? I have eaten at many other places in and around Union Square, spent 5 to 10 times as much money but never in that neighborhood have I had a meal that was so perfectly what I wanted and so perfectly made. Check it out if you are in SF and want a tasty reasonably priced meal. 

PS The breakfasts (served all day) look fantastic. I will try one next time!
author: Corey S.

description: $22 bottle of wine and breakfast 24 hours a day. Typical diner fare, and service, but a good Jack in the Box alternative for a late night craving.
author: Jennifer C.

description: After seeing the long line of tourists the previous day, I made a point of going early for breakfast the next day. But despite being a 24-hour joint, they really didn't get going for breakfast until after 7. So my order for two eggs and toast sat for 15 minutes and then got pushed behind a bunch of omelets and pancakes. So I avoided the wait for a seat but still sat around for about 25 minutes to get my breakfast. The price was not very good either but probably not too out of line for the Union Square area of San Fran - I paid over $15 for two fried eggs (with toast and hash browns) and orange juice. That's about 2 times what I pay in downtown Denver at Sam's #3. So how was the food?  Acceptable to good. The sourdough toast was good, but it's San Francisco so it darn well better be!!!  Most likely I will look for somewhere else when I'm back in the Bay Area next month.
author: Robert H.

description:
If you at all participated in - or even remember - late-night hangout sessions at diners with your friends swiping cold french fries off the vacated next door table back in your college days, you may appreciate this place. Well maybe not the potato product swiping, but I really like short order diners, and recall those days fondly. 

This 24-hour version is not really unique, except in the fact that it continues to survive while other similar diners are dying like flies. (That and the fact that the fry cook shot a waitress dead for putting in an order for poached eggs. No shit. Look it up on Google.)  It is situated in the heart of the Union Square boutique hotel district and serves up surprisingly delicious and fresh sandwiches and burgers. Try the tuna salad on toasted white with fries. Great milkshakes, breakfasts and diner food in general. 

And the people-watching out the large sidewalk facing windows provides great late-night urban entertainment. We won't even go into the details of who or what you might be so fortunate as to see.
author: Rick H.

description:
Had breakfast here one early (6-7am) Monday morning while on our honeymoon. Service was fast and the food was good. 

If I remember correctly you seat yourself and place your order at the counter but I could be wrong.

We would have gone back here but we wanted to try as many places as possible while in SF.
author: Amanda N.

description: Went in the evening, so I can't speak about breakfast. Our waiter was friendly and attentive, but there were only a few people in there. I got the fish and chips, which came with fries and some vegetables. The fish was good, but everything else tasted like it had just gone from the freezer to the fryer. This felt more like a quantity over quality restaurant. It's not bad, but it is overshadowed by all of the tasty restaurants close to it.
author: Joshua S.

description: Went here for breakfast one of our mornings in San Fran recently. Food was okay, decently priced. Might have been better if they weren't so busy. Was hungry, so anything tastes good. With no place else really catching our eye (and Lori's having crap service), this was fine for me and my family.
author: C.A. C.

description: This diner is well known in the area. I finally tried it and it lives up to the hype. The food here is excellent! Breakfast is done right here at this greasy spoon. Don't forget to tip these folks well. It only takes a couple seconds to see that these folks have to work hard to earn their reputation of great food fast.
author: Andrew W.

description:
I happen to thoroughly enjoy my time spent at Pinecrest Diner.  There are a few menu items to seem to allows rotate in ordering:

1)Spicy Chicken Sandwich ( ask for the sauce to come on the side, it's not that particulary spicy but they drench the chicken in and it becomes excessive sauce-ness).  Buck for buck this is the best deal on the menu for the price and the amount of food you get.

2)Pesto Chicken Sandwich.  A very tasty sandwich.  A large toasted bun, with HUGE chicken breast marinated in pesto, with cheese, tomato, onion, and lettuce.

It's a place to go when you have nowhere to go. But once you're ha;f way through your meal, theres nowhere else you'd rather be.
author: Chelsea C.

description: Poor service, horrible staff. Took forever to take our order, when they finally brought us the food they said we had to order something else since it was a $7 minimum per person. After we had already ordered. When we refused, they charged the extra $7 anyway.Talk about crooks and liars.
author: Angel T.

description:
Service is terrible , food is average and it's too expensive

won't recommended it at all
author: Talal A.

description: Nice breakfast spot with everything cooked fresh in front of you.   24 hours is a big plus however I didn't appreciate the rif raf.  But the food is great, try the steak and eggs
author: Tommy M.

description: pretty expensive but i like gravy and gravy is pretty good and they have gravy so ya know what i cant really hate on a place that has gravy isnt it awesome how u can put gravy on anything like biscuits or meat or bananas or coffee or whatever and it will still taste delicious man i love gravy
author: Charles Y.

description:
I went out to eat with a friend after hours one night, and surprisingly, in the bustling Union Square area, there were very few restaurants that were still serving food.  Pinecrest Diner had a neon "24 Hours" sign, so we went in.

For greasy spoon diner food, it was pretty tasty!  The menu was huge, with both dinner and breakfast options available, and I went for the spicy chicken sandwich, which was made with Franks Red Hot Sauce and had blue cheese.  Yum!  

It was also nice to get a meal in SF that didn't cost an arm and a leg.  I'd definitely go here again if I'm not in the mood for a long drawn out dinner at a high end establishment.
author: Katie H.

description:
