This place was across the street from our hotel and we had breakfast here before our flight home.

It was one of the most kick-ass breakfasts I've ever had. The place is open 24 hours, but when we got there at about 8am it was already packed and there were about 20 people waiting. We waited about 40 minutes to be seated, but that wasn't a bad wait considering. 

I had eggs, bacon, hashbrowns and chocolate chip pancakes which were to die for. They were $7 for a stack of three pancakes, so that was a bit pricey. Everything just tasted sooo good. Maybe it was because I was super hungry but I walked out real happy.

The service was very quick and I was really impressed because it was so busy; my boyfriend's coffee cup was never empty. Would definitely eat here again if we were staying in the same area!
author: Kellee N.

description:
I went here with Big Boss Man and he ate here the day before and wanted to do the same breakfast again.  Plus the line at Sear's and Lori's was too long. 

He ordered the Steak & Eggs, scrambled with some cheese and hash browns and toast. I would have gotten the same but wanted to be different. :)  It was a nice size steak and he didn't eat the hash browns.  But he was in love!  I got pancakes and side of bacon - being safe.  It was basic and decent!

Staff is quick and friendly to get fast turn on tables.  A lot of tourist here because it is convenient on the corner. But I'd rather wait in line or wait for lunch somewhere else.
author: Erika G.

description: Large portions, good breakfast food, always open. Had booths and counter space, good selection. Good wait staff, overall a nice place to go.
author: Summit M.

description: I recommend Pinecrest Diner if you're staying in the Downtown (Union Square) section of San Francisco. Food is on point, cooked to your liking, and fast service. Just keep in mind that its pretty small so try to get a head start to get in an get a seat.
author: Nike A.

description:
This is exactly what the sign says. It's a diner and nothing more. Even under new management, it's just lucky it's within a close proximity to Union Square. 
Walk in and sit wherever you'd like, the menu is just so simple and basic that's there's just no getting over the basics. Don't get any ideas about sampling the finest San Francisco fares. 
The decor is pretty cruddy, the cream and jam is sitting in monkeydishes right next to the predispensed syrup, ketchup and mustard. 
Don't get me wrong thoughithe service is top notch. The coffee will never go below half a mug, the bussers are attentive and there's never a rush to get you out nor are you ignored. I come here for breakfast and late night and both are good. Sit up at the counter and watch the short order cooks make your order.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Oh wow!  We had been walking all day, and every restaurant around Union Square had huge queues (it was Friday night), and as we trudged up Geary St, we stumbled across the Pinecrest Diner.  A fantastic 'American Diner' style restaurant, with friendly service and a huge menu. 
We ordered the Mediterranean Plate and it was delicious.  I thought I was back in Greece.  First came a lovely fresh salad with olives feta and lettuce and a delicious Greek salad dressing. Then came a big plate with fresh Tzatziki, lovely grilled chicken, greek salad and pita bread.  We scoffed that as well as spinach and ricotta ravioli, which was a small plate but so rich that we couldn't have eaten another bite.  
This was probably the best meal we've had yet, probably as it doesn't feel touristy or over priced.  Just delicious food, friendly staff and a lovely warm homey feel.   We will be back! (Oh - and the Coronas were only 5 bucks!)
author: Leigh O.

description: Three words: corned beef hash!!  Their corned beef hash breakfast makes my tummy so damned happy.  It is a bit pricey here though, when I go with my boyfriend two breakfast plates end up running us $30+.  The bathrooms downstairs are indeed very clean.  Docked off a star because we were rushed out last time.
author: Paige W.

description: Great traditional diner where if you sit at the bar table you get the view of freshly prepared omelets. I had the garden omelet which was amazing. I would only caution that it was quite warm next to the grill when sitting at the bar.
author: Sid B.

description:
The food is good, but the waitstaff doubles as cooks and puts their unsanitary hands all over your food. Maybe overreacting a bit, but I think if you're cashing someone out and then you put your hands all over my toast it's a little unsanitary. I asked for new toast from the manager after explaining to him why I wanted new toast and the other waiter not only did the same thing, I saw him wipe his nose then pick up my toast. I will never be hungry enough to eat that toast. This probably happens everywhere. I just don't want to see it. Didn't ask for free food, but it inspired me to sign up for Yelp.

Just go to Jack in the Box across the street.
author: Immanuel P.

description: This diner was not worth the payment we had to pay for. The coffee was very poor and expensive. We paid $80 here and only four of us ate. The food cost around $11 per person so how did it get to 80? The tip was includued so i was forced to pay it. The beverages were very expensive. There is a diner about 2 mins up the road called the olympic cafe which is way cheaper and in my opinion better food.
author: Paul W.

description: Delicious greasy spoon near Union Square. We all enjoyed our breakfast, french toast, pancakes, waffles, bacon. The side of bacon is like 5-6 big slices, good coffee.
author: K M.

description:
i dont really remember much of this place except that i came here after one too many drinks. im not sure if it was the food was why we returned or if it was that it was only a few blocks from our hotel and it was 24/7. 

what i DO remember... their corned beef hash tasted like heaven at 2am and it was even better with over easy eggs on top. :)
author: Janice S.

description:
This place has a killer morning omelette; and that is about it. Totally worth checking out if you're craving a greasy, American breakfast. The portions are large, and your breakfast always comes with a side of toast. But, honestly, I haven't been that impressed with the service. Even on the slowest day it takes at least 15 minutes to even be acknowledged by the server.

Easily knocked a star of my review.

That being said, once your order has been taken the food arrives pretty quickly. So, they've got that going for them.

TL;DR -- Omelette is delicious. Toast on the side. Service is lacking, but the food arrives quickly. Pretty standard greasy spoon of a diner.
author: Gabriel S.

description: Friendly, not very clean, omelets were good kind of runny in center, fresh fruit was good
author: Travel I.

description: If I was a betting man, and I am!  I'm laying 8:5 that you can't possibly find a better diner in the heart of San Francisco than here at Pincrest.  The salisbury steak is to die for!  Plus you get a big heaping mound of mashed potatoes, baked or fries, plus sauteed veggies, soup or salad plus drink for how much??  Like $12.50 ...get out of town..and the BEST breakfast also for pocket change.  When you go in, ask for Tommy, tell him TMac from Vegas sent you...Bet Pinecrest diner, and go to sleep!
author: Tommy M.

description: As far as diners go, Pinecrest is a pretty safe bet. When I went with my siblings for a Saturday brunch, we waited in line outside for about 30-45 minutes for people to finish so that we could have a table. We figured that it had to be good if there was a line that long for brunch. When we finally got seated, I had the french toast and my siblings both had omelettes. I'd have to say that all of it was alright. When it came down to it, Pinecrest offered solid diner options and friendly service, but that's pretty much it. Nothing too special, but a reliable place if you're jonesing for some diner food.
author: Katrina S.

description:
This is a typical diner so expect diner food.
Nice to know that it is ok 24 hours.
author: Ying S.

description: Went for a quick and simple breakfast on a Tuesday AM.  Got it!  Nothing fancy.  Good food, good service, short wait.  What more do you need?  Interior is super clean and comfy.  Don't expect gourmet, just good diner food.
author: Leah G.

description: A real american restaurant, just like you've seen in movies. And the experience is very good! Great food, ordered a supernacho. It were so much food that I only ate half of it. Superfriendly staff who ask if everything is good and if you want a refill on your soda. Recomended....
author: Jesper H.

description:
Ah, Pinecrest Diner at 3 or 4 am in the morning fills a particular spot in my heart (along with the other 24 hour diners sandwiched between Union Square and the 'Loin).  Trust me, it's not the food in particular that compels me to log this review -- though the breakfast food I usually order: stack of pancakes with a side of scrambled;  it's always more than sufficient for fending off extremely late-night hunger.

I enjoy random sketching, and the urge to do it strikes me at completely unpredictable hours of the day or night.  Recently, I've been lamenting the simple fact that San Francisco is not a 24-Hour Party All The Time City (thanks, Mr. Murphy).  Venues for sketchbook at those times outside of my own house have always been scarce.  That's where I've been grateful to the wait staff at Pinecrest for tolerating my presence in one of their booths for often hours at a time.  I do make sure I order drinks every couple of hours, but I'm still appreciative of the fact that they've never asked me to leave even as the diner fills up.  Also, the very-early morning crowd is often interesting enough to people-watch in amusement.  There's a future book in there somewhere.

Anyway, thanks Pinecrest!  I'll be cresting your pine again soo... errr, uh, never mind.
author: Adam E.

description: Great small diner.. nothing special, just decent food.
author: Peter H.

description: Great diner food.  I sat at the counter and enjoyed watching the cooks coordinate and present the food.  It was obvious the guys there take a lot of pride in what they do.
author: Kio K.

description: This used to be my favorite neighborhood go to spot for diner food until I got sick after eating here one night. I figured it was a one off and came back in today and ordered some french toast at the counter and was glad I ordered at the counter...I watched the cook handle raw meat bare handed then he put bananas on my breakfast with those same unwashed hands. Cross contamination...awesome. This will be my final trip to Pinecrest Diner.
author: Michael G.

description: Don't plan on staying long after you finished eating. They tell you to pay your bill cause people are waiting to sit.
author: Tracy B.

description: I didn't realise people come here sober. It always tastes just fine very late at night or early morning. Outside of those hours, it just feels like heartburn and stings of regret.
author: Sandy B.

description: It was a Sunday evening when my four friends and I walked in. Upon entry, it was clear that the restaurant was busy, and we were greeted shortly after entering, and seated by what appeared to be the host/expo. After some time we got to the waitress, who apparently was the only one working. She probably had something to the tune of 12 tables. In the short amount of times we saw her (3?) we were able to get our drinks, food (which was mediocre, consisted of the spaghetti, waffles, cheese fries and mozerella sticks between the group) and the check. My friends and I did not think to ask the waitress, who was clearly very rushed, to split the check before receiving it. When my friends and I approached the cash register to split the check we were told "I'm too busy for that, you should have told me earlier". Really? As the customer, you are saying that it is my responsibility to inform you of splitting the check with no signage insinuating that you do not regularly split checks? You didn't think that five people in there mid twenties would want to pay for their own stuff? Again, if there was a heads up or signage insinuating that this was the case then I would understand, but we did not have cash and I think it's pretty cruddy to think it's your customers job to tell you right up front that we need to split the checks. This may not seem like a big deal, but it was clear that the staff did not consider how we felt. Obviously I will not be returning, nor will my friends.
author: Quinn S.

description: Came here for breakfast during a trip to San Francisco.  I had the Pinecrest omelet and it was really good.  Prices are reasonable and service was fast.  Would definitely eat here again.
author: Kelli S.

description:
The most expensive glass of orange juice I've ever had!

I often come here during the wee-morning hours after a long night of  ripping it up on the dance floor. I rarely eat much more than a small breakfast, but it always seems to satisfy the club night munchies. Where it doesn't satisfy is the wallet, as the prices tend to be a little outlandish. Especially for breakfast at a diner. But the quality service and cleanliness make up for overpricing. Located in the tenderloin this place is like a pretty stone in the rough, not quite a diamond, but pleasant to look at.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Well it's diner food with history.  The short line of people to get in led me to believe that I was in for a treat.  I would liken this place to a truck stop diner.  Not bad, not great just good 'ol Americana... Iconic greasy spoon.  I have become too much of a foodie to appreciate the Pinecrest Diner.  
You will feel like your in an episode of Alice at Mel's Diner. 

You're not getting the great San Francisco food expereince here.
author: Robert B.

description: No complaints here.  No lengthy review, because it wasn't anything other than what you'd expect from a corner diner at night.  Good, plentiful food, decent coffee, and friendly service.  Nothing you're going to write home about, but a solid meal for a good price.
author: Scott S.

description:
I used to walk by this place daily when I lived up the block from Pinecest Diner. It looks the same as 13 years ago, nothing has changed. I've heard some good and bad stuff about this place, but I never really had the urge to try it. 

I finally stopped by after work Thursday and gave it a shot. I was getting some last minute Christmas shopping done in Downtown so I wanted a quick bite before i start. Came in around 6:05PM and the place was kind of empty, but did fill up fast as it gets towards 6:30. I ordered a bacon omelette which was not great, I've had better ones else where... I did corded my boyfriend the Reuben Sandwich, which is sliced corned beef. He said it was really good. 

I would come back again since they serve a big variety of food, from breakfast to pasta, sandwich and stuff.
author: Jenny G.

description:
For the price I paid I expected more. No coffee refills ever found their way to our table, the food was so bland and minimalistic it might as well have come out of a box, and the check was slammed on our table before we were even halfway through our disappointing breakfast. 

I got the eggs and ham, boyfriend got Belgian waffle and eggs combo plate. His plate was $11, but came with one waffle and one egg, both unceremoniously dumped on a plate with a sad little syrup container on the side. My eggs were done perfectly but the ham tasted like it had been frozen and unfrozen throughout the ages. Shit tasted old and funky. 

It's open 24 hours, but I know for a fact they will frown and scowl if you go there super late at night (early in the morning? Whichever, take your pick) and order something small like coffee and a slice of pie. You'd think they'd be stoked to at least make some money without having to really dirty anything up--it's a pre-made slice of pie and a pot of coffee you've had on since 5am. What's the big deal?

Anyway, I guess if you're downtown somewhere and Lori's is too busy to accommodate you (doubtful) this is a less-than-stellar option. Lori's also has friendlier staff that doesn't rush you out as soon as you sit down.
author: Meghan K.

description:
We had breakfast/dinner at 1 in the morning there on Thursday and I have to say I am a fan of this place now.  We often stay in SF, just down the street and we hadn't tried this place.

Everyone liked their food and thought the quality was great.  Everything was very fresh and it tasted great.  The service and prices were good also.

We tried to go there for breakfast the next day but it was packed.  Definitely on our list of places to eat when we are in SF.
author: Ashur K.

description:
I had a very enjoyable experience here. A friend and I were in San Francisco for the World Series Giant's Parade. With millions of people swarming around us, we walked our way from the Civic Center down to Union Square escaping the madness just in time. We stumbled past Pinecrest Diner and peeked in to see if it looked appetizing. We were tired and hungry so we gave it a go. 

We were seated within 5 minutes with a line out the door. The place was PACKED, every booth and counter seat was occupied. And still with that many people our food was hot and in front of us within 10 minutes. I ordered a cheeseburger with fries while Tina ordered bacon and eggs. And of course we split a chocolate milkshake. The food was scrumptious and the chocolate milkshake was REAL, more like a malt. Mmmmm :) Although they didn't give us the rest of the milkshake like other diners usually do. 

Moderately priced, this is a cute place if your looking for a diner ambiance and tasty American food.
author: Saralina B.

description:
As far as I can tell, this is the real thing.
Not fancy, but a real diner, with a great view of the corner,
and good solid food.

Stopped in for dinner with my wonderful wife.
Her meal was great, and more than she could eat.
Price was fair, and service was good.
I enjoyed sitting in this old corner diner,
and watching many different folks go by.
author: Curtis M.

description: First time I was having a breakfast here in 2008, then in 2010, then I've been there twice in 2013, and I will continue to eat there. Legendary place with HQ food and fast service. Worth to visit!
author: Nikolay S.

description:
Decent breakfast food and other typical diner fare.

The food isn't memorable either positively or negatively.

This place is open 24 hrs. so that's a bonus.

Obviously it gets crowded around 2AM on the weekends.

Pretty much, just a good place to go if you're a night owl or if you're out drinking.
author: Jason K.

description:
What an experience!  It is hot at the counter, but you get the entertainment of the cook juggling the demands of the masses in a very meek kitchen.
GREAT diner food!
author: Clint B.

description:
Bacon & Eggs, hash browns, Buttered Wheat Toast.
Standard fare, their hash browns and bacon are top notch.
author: Geordie E.

description: On a recent trip to San Fran I came across this place while shopping and starving. A little skeptical as its not much to look at but hey the menu looked amazing so what the heck. The service was great the side salad was huge and the Ruben was seriously amazing! If you're around this area you've gotta check it out for lunch!
author: Stephanie S.

description: My wife and I went there for breakfast.  My wife had eggs, bacon and hash browns.  All were cooked well.  I was going to order corned beef hash, but they said it was out of a can.  So I decided to get Huevos Rancheros.   Not so good.  It was 3 grocery store corn tortillas, topped with scrambled eggs, and a little store bought mild cooked salsa on top.  On the side was a scoop of black beans right out of the can and warmed up.
author: Al G.

description:
We desperately needed breakfast food at 12:30pm Sunday so we checked out of the hotel and walked over to Dottie's True Blue Cafe only to find a line halfway down the block. F***ing Guy Fieri. I like his show but once a place is on it, forget it. Good luck trying to get a quick bite.

So we walked a few blocks and settled on Pinecrest (btw, there are a ton of diners in this neighborhood - very nice). It looked like a diner, had a steady flow of people going in and served breakfast all day. Sign me up. Our party of four was seated instantly and our friendly waitress was taking our drink orders within a minute or two. I went traditional - Denver omelet, hash browns, toast. Hard to mess that up and they didn't. The food was out fast and in my belly even faster. More time for us to rehash the previous night's events. It was after all, a "mancation," as my buddy's wife called it. Four guys in SF for the weekend to catch a game, eat and drink. Somehow, none of us were terribly hungover and we weren't missing any body parts. We've either become pros at drinking or we're getting old. I'm guessing the latter.

Summary - solid diner, a bit pricey for what it is but you're in SF, suck it up. And if you use the restrooms downstairs, pick the one on the right. They apparently haven't gotten around to remodeling the one on the left.
author: Matthew D.

description:
I was in the mood to have breakfast food for lunch. Wandering around, Lori's Diner had a long line. Nope! Max's across the street was similarly full. Nope! Hmmm...Pinecrest doesn't look like there's a line. Off I go. 

It's full, so I sit at the counter. I wait. I wait some more. I read my Blackberry and wish I had a bought a paper. I wait some more. Just when I was thinking I should leave, the waitress asks me if I would like to order. Yes I would. I order a ham and cheddar cheese omelet with whole wheat toast. 

The short order cook was flying! I did enjoy watch him work the grill with ease and speed. I was less thrilled to see him eat some onion rings and not wash his hands. The eating part is fine, but please, wash your hands if you're going back to touching food. 

Luckily another cook who I'll give the benefit of the doubt made my omelet. It was OK. Done enough, but not much cheese. Toast had been sitting for a while and was soggy. 

I never saw the waitress again until she dropped off my check. Ed U. was right (as usual). Avoid Pinecrest. There are better places to eat.
author: Scott S.

description: Not the best service. Food so so... cornbeef hash looks like came from the can.
author: Elsie J.

description:
Bills itself as the best breakfast in SF. yes, it rocked. Get out of the hotel and walk down to this great place. Food wa fast and with a big smile. Regulars mixed with Internet-y peeps. Will come back for sure!

Had the omelette with hash browns etc. Full monty. Rocked.
author: Karsten R.

description: Pinecrest  Diner hits the spot for me.  I've gone there for breakfast and their service and food is consistently good.  Lately, after work, in the evening, I've gone in for a grilled cheese and fries,and have gotten the same good service.
author: Carlos C.

description: They advertise the best breakfast in SF - and this is one time they are right.  Fantastic omelets, great coffee.  Hash browns are not hard to cook, but to make them consistently perfect is tough, and the hash browns here are always fantastic.  Everything comes to your table super hot and fresh.  Old school staff knows their business.  No place to sit while you wait for a table is the only drawback.  The best call in the city for a belly busting late night breakfast after the bars close.
author: Ken P.

description:
Note to self, always check the Iphone Yelp application before entering a restaurant.

Atmosphere - Busy, diner style...duh, narrow, refreshed, noisy, clean, entertaining

Food - Ordered 2 eggs, 2 slices sourdough toast, hash browns, and ice tea.  All items were decent and fun to watch being made.

Service - Friendly and quick,...the short order cooks were fun to watch.

Price - All before tip $12...ouch!  It was very pricey for some eggs, bread, and potato.

Overall - Good experience, but way too pricey.  I should have read Yelp beforehand.  Yep, w/ Yelp I would have been forewarned.  Shortorder cook show changed this rating from 2 to 3 stars
author: Eric D.

description:
This place is famous! Watched the movie Funny People (which is a horrible movie and horribly long), and there was the Pinecrest right next to the theater Adam Sandler performs in. But this isn't the only reason to hit this place up, even though if it was-- you'd be cool via association. 

Owned by a hard working Greek family, you know the food will be good. I've been here on a Tuesday afternoon- amazing sandwiches. Saturday night/ Sunday morning post club outing- amazing and sobering hash browns, sourdough toast ( I mentioned I loved carbs, right?), and perfectly crispy bacon. Every time I've been here the service is great, and they're always packed. If you have a complaint tell the manager on duty and they'll do anything to make it better. I needed a straw and this pretty lady behind the register, I think her name was Sylvia, noticed I needed something and came and helped me; she had been dealing with an ATM problem but left it to help me. So nice! 

They recently revamped their menus, so now they have healthier options available. I've been to the Lori's diner across the street, enh it was like mall diner food, ie not very good- even when drunk. The Pinecrest also has good prices, especially for being one block away from Union Square. It would be someplace I wouldn't mind eating at a few times if I was on a travel budget. 

Currently they're under going renovations but I was told they'll open this Wednesday. I can't wait to see the new building and design. It'll def be better than the old 60's-ish diner vibe that it had before. 

Dear Pinecrest, expect to see me soon. I'd like sourdough toast and extra crispy bacon. Or maybe even a Turkey Club sandwich.
author: Jenna F.

description: Um...we got dessert first? We may seem part of the after hours party crowd but that doesn't excuse unprofessional service.
author: Dianne L.

description: We come here often after seeing a show at the various theaters close by. Usually crowded after a show, but worth the wait. It's typical diner food so you get what you expect to get at a diner, but the portions are big and the prices good. Food is good for the price and situation. Much better than Lori's across the way. recommended for after theater snack or food.
author: Bill D.

description:
I ordered the portobello burger, and was surprised how much I liked it. I wouldn't normally expect a diner to do such a good job with one - avocados, peppers and a delicious mushroom. Although I'm pretty sure a big reason it tasted so good was the mound of mayonnaise slathered on top. Sure, it defeated the point of eating a "healthy alternative," but made the whole thing tasty.

The service was fine - the waitress had no problem leaving and returning 3 times when I couldn't decide what I wanted. And the atmosphere is exactly what you expect from a diner (although I was a little weirded out by the dude next to me leaning over and asking for my fries). 

I'd go here instead of the Ruby's across the street, but I wouldn't make a special trip.
author: Nick P.

description:
Eaten at the Pinecrest Diner twice in the last six months, both times either pre or post ACT performance.  This is my go-to place if i don't want to spend a pile of money and am looking to eat good ole American food in a casual environment. 

Pros:  I love the fact that i can get breakfast in the afternoon/early evening.  Egg dishes and hash browns were great.  Great people watching since every table is along a window.  

Cons:  My friend went to use the bathroom and it sounded like he had to walk down several steep flights of stairs and walk through a subterranean maze to find it.  Friendliness of wait staff depends on specific personalities, i think.
author: D L.

description:
We just wanted a fast, cheap lunch. Noticing that the veggie burger was a dollar cheaper here than at Lori's, we went in. 

Cute little booths reminded me of the soda fountain my mom used to take me to after the dentist. Waitress was nice and the food was fancier than I expected. 

I agree with the other reviews that the fries aren't so great. But everything else was yum.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Came to Pinecrest one night at about 8:30 walking back to my hotel. It was not busy at all (about 4 customers total) and I ordered a Bacon Cheeseburger with Cheddar, and a Lemonade. 

The burger was a typical thin-patty diner burger. The bacon was tough and chewy, and the bun didn't have any flavor. The french fries were alright, thicker-cut fries that arent underdone, but not very crispy.

My bill was $12.80 w/out tip. To me this is a little higher than I would expect at a diner for a small burger and small lemonade, but I suppose for it's location it makes sense. 

I give them an extra star for being open 24-hours, I've only been once but I most likely will not come back.
author: Chris G.

description:
Me and my wife loved it. We had breakfast there every morning and tried different things every day. It was great all the time. It has the typical american diner atmosphere in a charming fashion and we felt very comfortable there.

I think it is fairly priced and I cant wait to get back there.
author: Tom F.

description:
early morning, late night, brunch, breakfast anytime at Pinecrest hits the spot. They make hash browns, not home fries, nuf said. 

but wait there's more! Pinecrest makes one of the best, artistic, robust Cobb salads...really! super fresh greens, ton's o bacon, blue cheese of quality. Yum! 

BTW, David's deli is just across the street, DON'T go to David's (see my review). Cross the street, eat at Pinecrest, save some money and gastronomic grief.
author: Jerry Y.

description:
Their awning claims, "We serve the best breakfast in San Francisco," which is I guess pretty bold. Still, they've been open since 1969, and the breakfast sandwich I had today -- ham, melted cheese throughout and egg on sourdough bread -- was perhaps one of the better versions I've had in a long while. 

Their coffee is strong, the booths allow for people watching inside and out on the street, and hey they're open 24 hours a day, in true diner fashion. And sort of thing never goes out of style. It's a little on the pricey side, but given its Union Square location, realize the owners and staff gotta eat, too.
author: Nish N.

description:
While my family was visiting in San Francisco, my son and i decided that we wanted a late night snack.  There are several diners in the Union Square area, but we chose this one, pretty much at random and based on the menu - which is pretty extensive.
Okay, it is what it is intended to be - a diner.  And, they do a good job at being a diner.  You can grab a quick bite, breakfast anytime and it's all diner tasty!  If you want plush or some divine presentation - go elsewhere.  This place serves food when you want it, and is very casual.  The wait staff is attentive and friendly.
author: Clint L.

description: Great service. Quickly sat and served; good food and open 24 hours!
author: Jordan A.

description:
One of those rarities in SF, a diner that's opened 24hrs.  It must be our weekend to dine in the Tenderloin with the drunks, derelicts and junkies.  The line at Dottie's was at least 15 bodies long (our 2nd attempt) and I was not in the mood to wait because I had to get over to Macy's.  So, we decided to give Pinecrest Diner down the street a try.  "It's an institution", Hubby tells me.  It's an old time diner with the vinyl booths and worn formica table tops with the bathroom downstairs in the basement.

The place is full of tourists who are probably staying at local hotels.  Their breakfast menu is 1/2 omelets and the other items are standard breakfast fare:  waffles, pancakes, ham (including Hawaiian ham), eggs, corned beef hash (the canned kind), sausage, bacon, etc.

Hubs really enjoyed his chicken fried steak, smothered in gravy with bits of ground meat (it was good) and 2 eggs, wheat bread and crispy hash browns (the frozen kind), $9.  I had the corned beef hash (Looked like Hormel's or Libby's) with hashed browns, 2 eggs and sourdough toast, $9.  Both were good, like the kind of stuff you'd find at Denny's or IHOP, so don't expect too much.  Portions are large and I ended up taking home 1/2 my meal.  

In the early hours until near noon, the staff is really hustling.  You can see most of the Latino cooks in the open kitchen running back and forth and watch them break a few eggs from the pile lined up on the counter.  Staff's friendly but hurried.  VISA and MC accepted.
author: Ry T.

description: We went for a quick dinner before the show. The waiter was really nice, the food good. We ordered simple dishes to stay on the safe side and we ended up enjoying them very much. Overall, a very honest diner experience.
author: Luca R.

description:
Aside from the fact that the table next to us who were seated after we were got their food far before we did, making us very agitated, this place wasn't half bad. 

I ordered the cobb salad. At first I kicked myself for ordering a salad at a diner. I envisioned wilted leaves and mushy avocado. But it was actually really fresh and tasty. The chicken was hot off the grill, crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. The tomatoes were ripe and sweet. The lettuce was crisp. I was shocked! 

Next time I'll probably order a hamburger. My brother ordered one and it looked damn good. I mean really, who orders a salad at a diner?
author: Julia N.

description: This place is cool cuz its haunted.  But its also not cool cuz its haunted with shitty food.
author: Fatty A.

description: The best breakfast in town, in spite of the sketchy service and an occaisonal curly black hair in your food.  The breakfast menu is complete and throughoug, and low priced too.   I had the eggs and hot-links.  Plenty of grease in this meal.  Exactly what the doctor ordered.  This place is my favorite indulgence. Gotta have it.
author: Biff T.

description: What can I say. It's diner food with an outrageous price tag. Service was okay, food was nothing special.
author: Eric B.

description: Best fried chicken in San Francisco!!!! Crispy, fresh, moist, delicious!!! Try it - you won't be sorry!!!
author: Eve G.

description:
Pinecrest... you get 2 stars but I keep going back. Why? Because you're open 24 hours and you're walking distance. 

It's greasy. The server has attitude. It's takes a long time to get your food. The breakfasts are pricey. 

Don't go here expecting great food. This is a place you subject yourself when you're having a late night craving from alcohol- or at least that's what the population inside the restaurant looks like past midnight. Beware- it's the whole 20 something bridge and tunnel crowd from Ruby Skye if you're after hours. 

Not a classy place by any means... however- there really aren't a lot of options as far as 24 hour places go. They get an extra star for creating a bizarre sandwich that was specially ordered.
author: Noel H.

description:
Standard diner fare. Better than Lori's, but not by much.

Atmosphere was good, like a real diner. People were focused on the business of eating, or maybe talking to their companions. Service was solid, although the waitress seemed a bit harried.

Costs more than a normal (i.e., not right next to Union Square) diner would, but you can (barely) squeeze in a meal under $10.

One surprise: juices are Odwalla juices and priced accordingly. $3.25 for a small orange juice is mildly ridiculous.

All in all, probably two-and-a-half stars, but not good enough for me to round up to three.
author: James B.

description:
I've got to give it 4. Just to balance out the three, at the very least.

Don't expect great food, nor great service, nor a squeaky clean table.

Do expect the following: a great neighborhood spot, a couple of TVs, available beer and above all, the most important, bacon and eggs and hash browns at any goddamned time of the day or night you want any of those things.

24 hour joints are rare in the city, and I would be willing to wager places with legit hash browns are even more rare...

In fact, I'm going to go get a beer and some hash browns right goddamned now.

Again, it's just a greasy spoon. Open 24-7. Not a bad place to swing through, and on the edge of a very  vibrant neighborhood.
author: Coe S.

description:
My friend and I went Black Friday midnight shopping and had taken public transportation all the way from Milpitas (Great Mall) to SF to continue our shopping spree. After spending almost three hours on a train or bus, all we wanted was some really solid, delicious breakfast at a comfortable diner.

To our sore disappointment, we got neither.

First of all, the actual place was unbearably cramped. We were seated in a booth right next to the door and not really in the "main" area. With the tubs of dirty dishes and greasy aprons all around us, I didn't feel at peace, which is what I expect at a traditional diner.

I ordered the Pinecrest Special because I have to judge every diner by its standard buttermilk pancakes. My friend got the Denver Omlet, which he said was decent. He also praised the hash browns. However, the pancakes were atrocious. They were chewy, flabby, and not fluffy at all. Non-fluffy pancakes will be the death of me one day. Even cutting them was a pain because the pancakes just had a terrible time separating, whether by knife or teeth. As for the rest of the dish, there really isn't any way to go wrong with eggs. Bacon was nice and crisp without any burnt parts. I don't enjoy breakfast sausage anyway, so I couldn't judge those. But the pancakes. God, the pancakes. I was nearly delirious with exhaustion and the pancakes stabbed a fork through my stomach.

The service seemed to be strangely poor towards me and my friend. It was at least ten minutes until we were asked by a busboy for drinks, and he couldn't take our our actual orders (ten minutes is quite a long time to decide for breakfast). Another five minutes went by until the actual server brusquely came over. Other people (like the people sitting behind us) somehow got near-immediate service, so I'm not sure what was up with that.

The only reason I'm giving this place two stars instead of one is because the people seem to be decent. I left a bag of things I bought from Black Friday, and when I ran back ten minutes later, the server calmly pointed me to behind the counter, where she had stashed it.

Still a disappointing experience.
author: Lawrence L.

description: Great greasy spoon.  I was there late at night, and had a delicious "Greek Patty Melt".  Classic diner ambiance, and - judging from the clientele and how busy they were - this place is very popular for the after-bar crowd.
author: Dave B.

description:
Had breakfast there a couple of weeks ago after a recommendation from the front desk of a nearby hotel...The place was packed so we were thinking this place must be good but we figured out quickly that it was not as soon as we sat in one of the filthy booths. The server took her time coming over and she was rushed and got impatient after we asked her for a recommendation. She wasn't very helpful at all.  

We ordered the pork chops and eggs - chops were flavorless, no salt, no pepper, no seasoning - basically a chop out of the package and thrown on the grill. I had the basic breakfast of eggs, hash-browns and bacon which were just ok. 

Our bill was over $45 for 3 small and average breakfast dishes. This place is overpriced, has terrible service and not very clean. Don't know how or why anyone would recommend this place.
author: Steve S.

description:
Not the fanciest food, or the most flavorful.  They're tragically understaffed and tiny.  Not that cheap, either, to be honest.  But if you do want simple food, at an ok price, served up relatively quick, near Union Square, you could do worse than Pinecrest Diner.

My mom, boyfriend and I were here on the 4th for dinner.  They only had one waitress for the entire place, which apparently pissed off another customer (she threw her credit card at the waitress and cursed a bit...), but given that it was a holiday, I guess I understand.

Their chili is a little flavorless and their hashbrowns aren't great, but you don't go to a diner for gourmet.  You go for quick.  And this place has that down.
author: Adam T.

description:
You can't help but to like this place, considering its been here since 1969, and has been attempting to live up to the sign in the window proclaiming they serve the best breakfast in San Francisco. Hahaha thats a pretty tall order there considering the city is a food lovers haven. 

While the place has seen better days, they still serve decent diner food, nothing pretentious just simple stuff, although don't ask for a poached egg, its not on the menu and the last time someone did, the cook shot the manager. 

seriously.

anyways yes, its a bit creepy downstairs for those that venture that far to use the restroom, and for a true gem of trivia, the Zodiac Killer ate here, 

seriously.

The Zodiac Killer got into the cab of one of his victims here on October 11th 1969. 

So anyways go on down the Pinecrest and have a bite to eat.

Seriously.
author: Cooper M.

description:
Ate here after a concert at the Warfield. It was after midnight, so it was hard to find a good place to eat. 

We were pretty hungry, but no one finished their food. Probably a good thing, too--don't eat so late.  =P

Eat here if you are looking for food, but "Meh. I've experienced better."
author: Joyce L.

description: Best corned-beef hash I've ever eaten and completely worth the wait for a table on weekend mornings. This place has been a staple of my trips to SF since I first went in 2004.
author: Kate S.

description:
After just an hour at a bar, it was 11pm, and my friends and I had major munchies. At first, we thought Denny's. But that was a BLEH idea, so we decided to walk downtown and check out our options.

We randomly walked into this place. I'm glad we did. I think my belly and my diet hate me though but it was worth it!. It was SO GOOD!

I ordered the omelet with avocado, bacon, cheese, and sour cream with hash browns and toast on the side. It was a little too cheesy for me but still YUMMY.

My friend ordered the bacon cheese burger with avocado. They forgot the avocado part =(, but when he told the waiter, he practically brought over a whole avocado on a small plate =)

My other friend had the super nachos. THAT was great! Gooey-cheesy, meaty nachos with sour cream. Can't go wrong.

I would definitely come back, but next time I'll share my dish. The portions were BIG.
author: Lisa G.

description: Pretty delicious for a dive diner. Grilled chicken, nachos with maple, and chicken tortilla soup highlights
author: Kenny M.

description:
Whenever I am in a city for any extended period of time I make it a point to find myself a good 24 hour diner. So it was a pleasant surprise to find the Pinecrest only blocks from my room. 

While the menu isn't as expansive as the "Greek Diners" I am accustomed to on the east coast, the (Greek-owned) Pinecrest's menu has the distinction of being without a single bad dish -- and over my six weeks here I've tried most of them. 

The staff is also incredibly friendly no matter what time you come in. This is an important thing to note as many all-night diners are notorious for cranky waitstaff. 

My favorites? The mozzarella sticks, the chicken pesto sandwich, and the milkshakes. 

The Pinecrest is infamous in local lore as the spot where, in 1997, a cook shot a waitress, by some accounts over an argument the previous day after the waitress admonished him for agreeing to make a customer poached eggs, which aren't on the menu. They still aren't. 

But with poached eggs or not, the Pinecrest is still a great spot.
author: Andrew F.

description: Three and a half stars! Food was above average and coffee was hot. They seemed really understaffed but we still got everything we ordered very quickly.I like the small home town feel, and hearing how everyone had there own  conversations going. Great feel good food!!!
author: First Name H.

description:
I was in San Francisco and saw the diner that said the best breakfast so we decided to try it. When we first walked the front door it was broken off the hinges and hanging on the side of the diner. Our wait was only about 5 min for a table and we were stoked but when we sat at the table it was soo cold from the front door being broken I had to get my kids jackets to eat during out meal. We sat for about 25 min before I flagged someone down to ask for hot coffee and milk for my kids; I quickly received them.  We waited another 15 min to get a waitress to take our order and I ordered two meals for my kids and she asked if that was all; we had four people at our table.  I ordered the new york steak and eggs and my husband ordered the corned beef hash and eggs; and two pinecrest specials for the kids at $11.00 a plate.  The kids meals came out after about 15 min and the adult meals came out like 10 min later.  The steak was tender and completely flavorless, the food got so cold soooo fast due to the front door being broken and then cold wind blowing in the diner. We had to ask for napkins and water, the customer service was horrible; no smiles, no greeting, and she didn't check to see how our food was or if we needed anything.  I had to get up to the register to pay the bill since she never came back. To feed two adults and a 3 and 8 year old it cost $56.00 for a bunch of crap.  Save your money and go elsewhere.
The bathroom were down three flights of stairs and stunk like urine, my 3 year old son used the toilet (sitting) and when a grossed out look on his face asked what the smell was; I told him pee pee and he said Ewww.  The bathrooms were clean other than that.
author: Eliz H.

description:
My go-to breakfast spot. I've been here a dozen times over the years and the breakfasts continue to be excellent. Not fancy food, but served hot, fresh, tasty, and quickly. No attitude or pretension, good service, lots of re-fills, and smiles.

Big thumbs up for a diner that does what it does honestly and well.
author: Bill G.

description:
I live just up the hill from this place, and it absolutely blows my mind that I can walk in at any hour of the day or night and be served a perfect bacon-avocado burger with crispy fries by a cheerful waitress!

I see a lot of 3-star reviews here with nothing negative to say.  Don't be stingy people!  I have standards too -- I can't finish a typical fast-food burger because it just isn't appetizing enough.  When I'm super-hungry for a full meal, and especially if it's 4am, I come to Pinecrest!
author: David G.

description:
I've now been to this diner 2 times. One time was midday. I was on a lunch break at work and needed to grab a bite. A coworker and I stopped in because it looked like a cute little diner. The second was late night after a birthday celebration with some friends.

Both times service was slow. Both times I was physically ill afterward. I don't know, it could be my stomach however each time I ordered something totally different. For lunch we shared the nachos which had the fake nacho cheese sauce rather than actual melted cheese and some other random topping. Late night I ordered the Denver omelet. The food always tasted mediocre and did the job, but 15-30 minutes after eating I was nauseous both times.

I will not be going back I am sure there are other diners with better food and a nicer staff.
author: Crystal C.

description:
This is a classic diner in the Union Square area of San Francisco.

Although it looks kind of dumpy from the outside, it's actually pretty nice on the inside and the food is surprisingly good.

I'm a big fan of Joe's Special omelets (ground beef, spinach, onions, cheese etc) and there's is the best I've had.  The Farmer's omelet is also quite good.

For lunch/dinner, I've tried their burgers which are surprisingly big and the chicken fried steak which is pretty good as well.  

The service here is prompt and efficient and friendly enough.  Although, it is clear that they don't really want diners to linger.  The seating here is valuable and they want to turn over the tables quickly.  During busy dining times, there is typically a line.

This place offers great value for the area.  The portions are huge.  In fact, if you dine here first, you probably won't need much else the rest of the day.  And that's saying something because I'm a big eater.

Rating - 

Overall - 4 stars
Service - 3 stars
Food - 4-5 stars depending on what you order
Value - 4 stars

I would say the food is probably slightly better/more consistent for breakfast than lunch/dinner.

Try it out!
author: Doug M.

description:
Standard diner food. Probably would have died over it, had I been drunk but alas I wasn't. And like all other diner food when sober, it was decent.

I'll probably not remember this place, come in here stumbling drunk and think it was something completely different. And I'll come back here, shocked that I had already eaten here.
author: Lauren S.

description: This place did not do it for me. I didn't like the taste of the chicken apple sausage or turkey bacon. I asked for medium scrambled eggs and they were too hard. The hashbrowns were ok and the pancakes were decent, hence my 2.
author: Sunita M.

description: If you have a party larger than 4 don't bother coming. We had a party of 6 and they said they couldn't accommodate such a large party. They said they would have to sit us separately. We didn't mind and just crammed all 6 in one booth. It was a little tight, but we made it work. The food is decent. Its nothing to rave about. It's a step up from denny's or IHOP.
author: Si O.

description: Ate breakfast here two days in a row and definitely would recommend if you're in San Fran and in the Union Sq / Tenderloin (eww!) area.  Traditional American diner with lots of charm and simplicity.
author: Peter Y.

description: Pass by this area see this place usually busy with people. Decide to have brunch with my girlfriend. They wasn't busy was greet when inside the diner. Seating was free open. We order Short stack Chocolate Chip Pancake and Grill Chicken Pesto Sandwich with fries. Quality for food was good for the price asking for. Quick service and waiter was nice check on us to see if we good. They serve unlimited coffee refill. Good small diner. Recommend to eat here and would come back here.
author: Gruber T.

description: We had the Pinecrest omelette and the Meat sauce spaghetti. The omelette was pretty good but the spaghetti was just average. And don't expect any service.
author: Donald W.

description:
I only gave it two stars because all I had was the iced tea and it was not
fresh-brewed! After being shunned from an art show down the street (which I was invited to but somehow didn't end up on the guest list) my friends and I retired to this quirky diner. Two of my friends got beer, my other friend and his daughter shared a banana split and I, the tea. It was instant tea! Not even on my travels in the South did I ever come across tea so wretched. The banana split, which I had a bite of, was just so-so..nothing fancy. What intrigued me was the bathrooms which was an adventure in itself. Remember that scen in 'Spinal Tap' where the band can't find their way to the stage and end up wandering aimlessly around? It was just like that!
Kudos for the waitress. Not only was she an attractive and humorous, she was effective as well. Great place for looking at people, gathering character references for one;s book or ideas for painting. I should go back and try some of their breakfast dishes that people rave about.
author: michael s.

description: I sat by the door. Anytime it opened, the wind felt like a ghost weakly slapping me with a cold palm.
author: Mustafa S.

description:
typical saturday morning for a local. wakeup, hungering for noms, check nearby alternatives and default to a diner.

4 star greasy spoon type food. satisfying. I was in a good mood so I wasn't ruffled by the fact that they wouldn't let me spend 10min after we finished our food to finish my second cup of coffee so yeah a 2 star service experience. 

cozy atmosphere and booths, coupled with the fact they don't let people sit for long during the breakfast rush makes this a good spot to get a solid breakfast without having to wait for a table.

did I mention I'm in a good mood?
author: Karsten M.

description:
Whilst visiting San Francisco on holiday from the UK we tried the Pinecrest Diner for lunch one day.

I would describe it as pretty average.  I had a tuna sandwich was ok and filling but a bit uninspiring.  My wife had a tuna melt.  Both were accompanied by a generous portion of fries but they were fairly dry and I could have done without them.

I can't see me going back on my next trip to San Francisco whenever that might be.
author: Mike S.

description: Reasonable prices for a decent breakfast. Had the yogurt and fresh fruit so it would be hard to mess that up. It's nice to visit this cafe with its old world charm in this big city. We didn't order any food that required cooking so I couldn't speak about other dishes but they looked good. We didn't have a long wait and were very satisfied.
author: Leslie C.

description:
I always pass by here, and decided to drop in and order food. I heard the breakfast here is good, but I never order the breakfast items. So I can't tell you about that.

However, when you walk in, the people there don't really greet you. You're kind of just standing there until they notice you and usher you to a table. 

And I wouldn't recommend getting the chicken. Even if it looks cooked on the outside, it was still fresh on the inside...explaining me and my mother's current stomach problems. Ugh.
author: Annie D.

description: standard diner, nothing differentiates this place... busy (especially at night after the nearby clubs close)
author: Rocky C.

description: Decent dinner food for anytime of the day.  I love coming in here at 3am with my Kindle and a bottomless cup of Joe.  People need consistency in their lives, and this place is one in mine.  It's always up when I am!
author: John D.

description: This is a 2 minute walk from the Clift Hotel and was happy that unlike the Clift, this had more substance and style didn't matter too much.  Ordered the Corned Beef Hash and the Hawaiian Ham.  It's hard to muck up breakfast but on the same token, it's hard to elevate the classics.  What set this place apart for me were a few things.  Staff was pretty efficient in spite of the chaotic breakfast crowd.  I ordered take out and was surprised at the portions.  Hash browns were proper and really good.  The corned beef has was one of the better ones I've had in awhile.  The bonus was although being in the heart of downtown, they didn't charge an arm and a leg.
author: Es P.

description:
Came here for breakfast one weekend morning. Got to sit @ the counter and not a booth so we were right behind the grill...good choice. My g/f and I both ordered a omelet made with local and fresh ingredients which I was very impressed with. The service and atmosphere is typical in a diner but not bad and not dirty. The portions were huge and neither one of us could clean our plate. Everything that was sent out that I saw looked delicious. We tried to come back the next weekend but it was full.
Would definitely recommend coming here for breakfast.
author: Matt F.

description: This was quite an experience!  The food was not very good, but we did get to witness some hookers at the table next to us agruing with some guys at the table next to them the whole time we were there.  Granted, it was 3am, but that's what gives this place their 3rd star- it was packed and exciting!  Just whatever you do, please do not go into the bathroom.
author: Jamie B.

description: Sorry Pinecrest.  Mama always said, look at the bathrooms.  That's the area they let the customers see.  If the restrooms are a mess, (and they are) the kitchens even worst.  And the food's not bad for greasy, overpriced diner food.
author: EC N.

description: Tried this place for breakfast and really liked it. Not too expensive, and great selection! 24 hours too.
author: Michael K.

description:
Dirty, greasy, filled with tourists. The kind of place you'd expect to find on the edge of the Tenderloin and Union Square across the street from a major dance club, and sandwiched between various hotels.

We came in uninebriated, searching for something hearty to fill our very empty stomachs after our last evening of manual labor in the East Bay. 

Pleasant servers, filthy kitchen. Their breakfast menu is served 24 hours a day.
author: May T.

description:
It's just shy of 2am.

You have just consumed about 6 strong arse vodka drinks at Rye on a school night.

You are starving.

What in the backstreet boy hell are you gonna do?

Ooooh, 24 hour greasy spoon diner, kitty corner to your hotel! Sweet!

And so we went to Pinecrest last night to get a little padding for our pending hangovers. The meals of choice....grilled cheese, fish n chips and of course CHILI CHEESE FRIES. (And I wonder why guys are dumping me sighting "not active enough" as the reason!) 

Anyhoo, I can't vouch for the grilled cheese as I didn't partake in it, but judging by the fact that there wasn't any of it left on my girl's plate and she was smiling like a kid on Xmas day, I will take that as a good sign. My fish n chips were okay, but I didn't even bother finishing them after picking up a chilified, cheesytastic scoop of wet soggy fries and filling my mouth with happiness. Good Lord, there are few things better than that at 2am with a buzz..

And so, will you find a 5 star meal here, hell no.
Will you bring mom and dad here when they are visiting from out of town? Hell no.
Will you contemplate selling your first born for another bowl of chili cheese fries as you sit writing this review at 2:03am...oh HELL YES!

24 hours! Gotta love it :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
all good here best diner on the west coast as far as im concerned. food taste clean  
love the hot links here for some reason

prices not bad 
staff friendly
author: Mike A.

description:
If you take the Sunday paper here and try to enjoy it with your breakfast/coffee the rude ass waitresses will come and hang all over you and try to hustle you through eating.

They will then take the paper from you and hand you the check.

You will be less knowledgeable about the world from not having been able to finish the paper and you will have indigestion from being forced to eat too fast after leaving the Pinecrest Diner.  Not to mention you'll be cranky b/c you'll have tipped the rude ass waitress despite her bad behavior b/c you are too nice to stiff anyone in the service industry on a tip - having worked in the service industry yourself - the fact that you only leave 10% on a breakfast check will be of no comfort.

This is not a good way to start a Sunday.
author: Kate R.

description:
My friend and I ate breakfast here twice on a recent trip to San Francisco.  The food was great and the service was snappy!   The second time we came in, it was later in the afternoon and the place was still packed.  

Had we been hungry late at night, I'm sure we would have eaten here again as we realized that this diner is open 24 hours. 

It's only a couple of blocks from Union Square.  There were a lot of restaurants around to choose from, but this one was really really good.

We would definitely eat here again.
author: Karen C.

description:
I ate at this snazzy little diner while completely sober, alert, and substace-free - and I still give it a solid 3.5 stars!  The food was plain but very tasty.  I went here for breakfast when my boyfriend had the day off - we both got scrambled eggs, toast, and hash browns, which he didn't like but I thought were cooked perfectly (don't you just hate hash browns that are burnt on the top and all white in the middle?!?)

The service was friendly and very fast - although I got the wrong kind of toast at first, I mentioned it to the waitress and she brought me the right kind in about 1 minute flat.

The only thing that I missed was more variety on the menu... I know it's a diner with simple food, but they could come up with a little creativity!  Breakfast options were pretty boring and kind of expensive for just plain bacon and eggs.  I'll definitely come back here if I'm already in the area and hungry for breakfast in the middle of the night, but I probably wouldn't come out of my way to visit this place otherwise.
author: Laura W.

description:
There's something about Pinecrest I just really like.  The comfort of being in a diner that has been around for decades (and still looks like it!) makes me happy.  

24 hour diners rock.  If you're eating at 3am, it's most certainly not for a gastronomical experience, it's for a greasy carb and fat experience.  That is exactly what I want when I go to Pinecrest, and that is exactly what I get.  Mission accomplished.
author: James M.

description:
There is only one single reason to patronize this establishment: The Zodiac Killer.

Way back in the sixties, cab driver Paul Stine picked up his last fare in front of The Pinecrest. The passenger had him drive up to Washington Street, where he was paid for the trip in a currency of hot lead.

There are some that believe that the Zodiac ate here before he took the cab ride of infamy. Local legend says that for years, a zodiac message could be seen in the basement. This may or may not be true, as that I did see something that could either be by the murderer or just someone with a warped sense of humor. In either case, it was painted over a few months later. As a matter of fact, any Zodiac-related graffiti, especially in the men's bathroom is a sure-fire way to get them to paint the walls practically overnight.

But make no doubt about, just because SF's most infamous free-lance executioner might have patronized this establishment does not mean that you or anyone outside of being an insane masochist should dine here. Here's why:

1. Wait staff with bad attitudes.
I don't know if it's the borderline location to both the Tenderloin and Union Square, but if you look the least bit "alternative" (aka freakish), chances are, your service will be slow to non-existent. Don't expect service with a smile. Forced endurance with a scowl would be a closer descriptive, as the waitress tosses the menu practically at you (if you ever get that far).

2. Bland to mediocre cooking.
I guess the theater crowd, who seem to be the only people who keep this farce of a diner from going under, either have no food taste, or will eat anything when they are food-slumming after a show. In either case, the food is bland, generic, and far overpriced.

3. Sanitary Conditions.
While vermin aren't noticeable, other factors are. Let's just say that cleanup policies are "relaxed." The last time I stopped in, most of the tables were in dire need of being cleared off and/or wiped down, and remained that way the entire meal.

So if you must stop in, be it for Zodiac folklore or for  the kitchen poached-egg murder, just order a soft-drink, better yet a cup of coffee, or tea or something that's been boiled. Just whatever you do, do not order the food, or mention The Zodiac or Poached Eggs.
author: Randy M.

description:
Everywhere we wanted to eat was at least a 45 minute wait, so we took a stab at this diner as we were seated immediately. 
It's your average diner, not great, not horrible. I got the mushroom and swiss burger - my boyfriend got the patty melt. Both very standard but tasty. The breakfast around us looked good, and they are supposedly the best breakfast in SF.
author: Nicole S.

description: Awesome homegirls fell good meals!
author: Tamara W.

description:
The whole of the experience was between, "Ooookaaayyy," and "Oh my god!"  The food is WAY below par; my food was cold when I got it.   The waitress looked like she was straight out of a cartoon, but she looked like she probably stuck her cig butts in people's food.  The downstairs bathroom is very reminiscent of a horror movie death scene when you scream, "No! No you idiot!  Go the other way!"  My sister and I didn't dare sit on the toilet and weren't sure if the soap dispenser actually dispensed soap, so...
I say, there are other places close by that are better than this place.  Please do not go here.
author: Veronica S.

description:
It looked like a nice old style diner, which made me wanna go in for omelet for the breakfast.  

I ordered Beverley Hills Omelet (about 10 bucks) with avocado and ice tea.  My wife was not hungry, so she was gonna order hot tea.  Then, the waitress pointed out "minimum $7 per person" policy at the bottom of the menu with her finger.  The total was already more than $7 per person, but it's OK.  We will come up with something to make the requirement.  But, what she said next with an agitated face just shocked me.
"You have to order $7 minimum for each, or leave"

The moment she said "leave", I felt very offended and instantaneously stood up and left.

What an unprofessional service!!  Before I started my current career, I was a waiter at the restaurant with a certain policy.  Sometimes, we encountered customers who did not meet the requirement.  But we always did our best to make ends meet, because those customers are there to enjoy our food and services.

The waitress/waiter are big part of the team in the restaurant business.
This waitress deserves only 1 star, then this restaurant deserves only 1.
author: Yoshi D.

description: Good food.  I enjoyed the Rueben sandwich and my friend enjoyed the Cobb salad.  Both were healthy portions of food.  Coffee was good, service was good.
author: Peter S.

description: Great little dinner with attentive and friendly staff. Had a great Reuben and the fries were made excellently. Would eat here again, but don't expect anything other than diner food.
author: Selcuk S.

description:
Midnight breakfast... Standard two egg breakfast. Nothing spectacular, but was filling. A bit greasy and had an interesting ambience to it. Not sure if I would go back again- only because SF has sooo many great places to eat. 
Pricing per plate was roughly $8-20 (?)
author: Wendi W.

description: Great spot to be anonymous, sip coffee and read. Food is decent; what you would expect from a diner. Service was excellent!
author: Britt Q.

description:
This was the worst meal I've had in weeks.  I got a reuben.  The pastrami was tough and gristly, the cheese was not melted.  Iris got chocolate chip pancakes.  They do not put the chocolate chips into the pancake batter.  Instead they throw a handful of chips atop the finished pancakes and add $2 to the bill.  Their ham is poor quality, with lots of water added; perhaps it came out of a can.  Their coffee was sour and watery.   

We went there looking for an alternative to the expensive hotel breakfast.  Big mistake.  Cheese omelet, two pancakes with chocolate chips, reuben, side of ham, and two cups of coffee cost $47.  The expensive hotel breakfast would  have been cheaper and ten times better.  

Service was indifferent.  The food did not come quickly, and my request for extra napkins went unheeded, even though the baby had spilled water on the table.  The restaurant was only half-full, but the staff acted as if they were slammed.

I did not visit the bathroom.  Lorrie came back from there and said that it was best left undescribed.

How can this place survive?  Sure, it's open 24 hours and is up the street from the youth hostel, but there is another 24-hour diner across the street and a 24-hour Indian restaurant around the corner.  I am stumped.

The sign says "best breakfast in San Francisco".  Having now eaten two breakfasts in San Francisco, I can attest that this is mistaken.  In fact, it may possibly be the worst breakfast in San Francisco.
author: Sudo N.

description:
I wish SF had more diners. And not those "we're a kooky Americana throwback with lots of polished chrome and a jukebox filled with golden oldies" diner. I'm talking REAL diners, the greasy spoon variety where you can raise your blood sugar and cholesterol levels to dangerous levels, smoke at the table, and do it all for around six bucks.

Why Waffle House has not yet become a truly national franchise is beyond me. Greasy, cheap, open 24 hours, old-timer rednecks at the counter checkin' you out when you come in...OK, maybe the "Awful Waffle" wasn't perfect. 

The Pinecrest Restaurant comes close to what I NEED in a diner. Although it doesn't have that ridiculous "Waffle House Family" song on the jukebox, the fact that somebody got whacked at the Pinecrest because of poached eggs is a good enough alternative (because trust me, someday, somebody is gonna get shot when that song comes on. If you've heard it, you know what I'm talkin' about).

Gotta knock off one star because of the prices. Then again, they are about the same as you are going to pay at Mel's or Lori's or (yecch!) Denny's.
author: Derek R.

description: The best hash browns I've EVER had and I've had quite a few breakfasts in my lifetime.   The french toast was tastey too! My friend had the pancakes and just loved them.  Back to the hash browns one order was more than enough for two ladies to share but you might not want to, they were that good!
author: Dawn D.

description: Drunkenly waiting 15-20 minutes for deep fried food at 3am here felt like waiting in line behind a crying baby shitting his pants at Disneyland.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Okay. So my friend and I went here TWICE in the same night. The first time we got pancakes, chicken, and scrambled eggs. These were all to go. We were a bit put off because the woman who worked there told us she had put enough syrup packets in our to-go bag. 
We go back to our hostel to find that there were only -two- small containers of syrup for four LARGE pancakes. But we decided we could always eat them in the morning and find some more syrup then(we never did). The food was pretty good. Their eggs were delicious. 

The second time, we were pretty drunk(about an hour later), and then we ordered Belgian waffles. MmmmmMmmmm. They were very good. 

The place was pretty decent but very smokey. I'm a smoker and if you sit in the front, you feel as if you've smoked a whole pack of cigarettes by the time you leave. A small price to pay.

I will go back again and this time I'll get my own damn syrup packets.
author: Ja J.

description:
I gotta give them 4 stars. This is not a faux diner,...this is the real deal and has been on this corner forever. A much better burger then you would get at Max's or Lori's Diner, both of which are across the street from Pine Crest. Better fry's too!. A real grilled cheese sandwich , made from some sort of processed mystery cheese, but soooo much better then all the fancy grilled brie sandwich's you find in the "pretend diner's near by. 

Oh yeah, it's open 24 hours a day seven days a week. Breakfast served all day. Good pies and OK shakes. At night this place is straight out of an Edward Hopper painting.
author: jeff b.

description: They sucked us in alright by the damn sign and the stupid tourists we were, we fell for it...the sign that said "we serve the Best Breakfast in San Francisco" I should have known better and turned back while we had the chance.  We proceeded in for the "best breakfast" which I must say was not anything spectacular.  The food was mediocre, decor was tacky and so were the tables as it felt like someone had spilled something on my side and it was only partially wiped up.  The city is expensive no matter where you go especially in the Union Square area.  If you are right in this particular area, are hungry, and Max's is open, go there.
author: Denise A.

description:
I love love love this place.  It probably hasn't changed much since the 60s.  I love that.

On to the food. I say, "Anything smothered in chili is delicious."  And Pinecrest delivers, bitches!

You can get a bowl of chili.  

You can get an omelet smothered in chili.

You can get a BURGER smothered in chili.  

Seems like everything is about $8-$10, right in line with every other restaurant in the City, so I am not sure what the griping about the $7 min. is about...  I am a value whore, and I have never been disappointed at Pinecrest.

I have even taken dates here.  And I took my parents last night.  They loved it.  And just for the record they're not Midwestern tourists.  I grew up in the South so whatever!

Actually my dad said "Aaaah, just like the Waffle & Egg (a lovely little 24 hour joint in my hometown)".

It's like a little slice of real America in sometimes-stuffy San Francisco.

But ya pay for it of course 'cause rent ain't cheap, ladies.

Loves it.
author: Dwayne A.

description: Very unfriendly. Bad and slow service for a diner. TOTALLY AVOID. I went there with my baby and wife. We were not even served water or coffee for more than 10 mnts despite multiple reminders. We finally decided to GET UP and LEAVE - the bearded guy who "runs" the place says " I don't care - have a line of people outside " ...went across to Lori's Diner - 10 times better !
author: AMIT A.

description:
It was breakfast time and they have advertised the best breakfast in San Francisco, but for some reason the Cobb Salad called my name...and thank God it did! So impressively good, and probably because my expectations were very low. Mixed wild greens, an entire sliced avocado, delicious bacon, perfectly grilled chicken and on and on. Husband ordered an okay omelette and the coffee sucked. The service seemed spotty and we were lucky to have arrived at just the right moment when we didn't have to wait and the waitress promptly took our order. I think one woman was handling the whole restaurant. Also the trip to the bathroom down in the catacombs of SF was scary and dirty. So in general the place gets 2 or 3 stars, but that salad is 5 stars, so....I went with 4.  
I would go back specifically for that salad.
author: Erica C.

description:
I vaguely remember ordering a Patty Melt.

I stumbled away from our table to pee.  The boys ordered 3 sides of fries and a round of diet cokes and coffees.

This can only lead me to believe it is sometime after 2AM.

Finding the bathroom was like the fucking Blair Witch Project.

I was gone for hours.  Must have been

I stumble back up the stairs.  There are so many plates of fries on our table I start to believe that at least 1/2 of them are figments of my imagination.

I sit down. (I fall down)

I stare at the plate in front of me.  Fries.  And a Patty Melt.

I look at the grilled concoction with disdain.

"Who ordered this?  Is didn't order thisss?"

"You did."

I push the plate away.  It hits one of the many plates of fries and tips a cup of coffee.

"No I dinnit.  Dinit.  Didn't.  I can't eat this."

Ryan was all too glad I denied the meat and took a bite.

I think i ate a french fry and immeadiately regretted it.

I almost puked in the cab ride home.

This, in no way, shape or form, is due to the food at the Pinecrest - aka - Shady Pines.

This, I blame, on the 5 drinks at the Gangbang.  The Bangway.  The Gangway.  The gay sailor bar.  Yeah.

Three stars for late night creepiness and french fries.
author: Jen I.

description: Solid and tasty diner experience pretty much anytime you need a fix. I enjoy sitting at the bar. Cooks and wait staff are great.
author: Matthew S.

description: A friendly, good value little place in the heart of the city. The burger tonight was bloodier than it should have been, but every other trip (3 total) has been fine. Open all hours! A better American experience than the chain diners, but perhaps that's just me...
author: James C.

description:
Upon walking into this place and sitting down, I asked myself...what did I just get myself into?  One word...blech.  

A few more words...well actually conjectures... Costco Pie, Chili from a can, tuna melt with American cheese..ok I pretty sure that last one is fact...either way, I won't be back anytime soon...well unless I'm drunk and hungry in Union Square.
author: Vikash G.

description: The customer service in this place is great and the food is pretty good. Granted it's not Ruth's Chris, but hey it's a diner open all night. If I was grading them on french fries alone they would be a solid 5 star. The place is clean and the service is fast even during busy hours.
author: Cedric C.

description:
Max's doesn't have pork, no surprises, but when I'm hungover I need pork grease. That's how I originally ended up at the Pine Crest. It is a decent facsimile of an east coast greasy spoon with good people watching.
I've been a half a dozen times in the last 4 years, always hungover.
I sit at the counter eat a greasy breakfast w/pork sausages and bacon read the paper and have some bad coffee. Nobody hassles me. I walk out feeling marginally better.
author: Sean M.

description: Breakfast was great but service was rushed, waitress would disappear longer than expected, nice it's open 24 hours
author: Ed P.

description:
Okay so i stayed at the king george and i made the bad mistake of swallowing some tap water.  Because of the bad pipes that made my room yak-ville for the next five hours.  Shortly after my goofy fiance after hearing me complain that it must be the water sticks his hand under the faucent and chugs down a few handfuls.  There we are.  Taking turns paying homage for the next two hours.

Some time around twelve it struck me that if only i could get something on my stomach i might be able to stop dry-heaving.  So i went downstairs to see if they had anything to eat.  They didnt.  It boasted 24 hrs at the top but this crazy korean guy chased me out of there.  What the hell?  The door was open... 

So i walked down to Pinecrest and the nice girl there set me up with two burgers to go with sodas even though it didnt look like they really did take out - she ran with it.  I gave her a nice tip.

I went back to the hotel and ate and BOY did those burgers taste great.   It cured us!
author: jacqui w.

description: Solid Dinner food. I had the Spanish omelet for breakfast and can recommend it.
author: Frank W.

description:
Pinecrest Diner can either be a hit or a miss with folks, unfortunately there doesn't seem to be a middle ground for it.

With all the tourists and businesses around, it's always a safe bet that the Diner is packed for the lunchtime rush. Since the staff never tries to push out any of their customers, waiting for a table can range anywhere from 15mins to an hour or more.

I've come several times after midnight, even when the bars and clubs get out it's never difficult to find an open booth. However, Diner customers have been known to be harassed and/or mugged by the homeless and the drunks who hang around the area. 

Try the Chicken pesto sandwich!
author: Cali T.

description: Visiting SF for work (from UK) and wanted to try a traditional american diner. I was definitely was not disappointed, the food was fantastic and the staff were very pleasant.  Portions sizes are enormous (by British standards) and prices are very reasonable. I will be visiting a few more times before I go home.
author: James N.
