description: This place is all bad! The food is crap and the service wasn't so great! I always have such a great experience with diners in the city but this one for sure was a horrible one! I barely touched my food!
author: Rachel D.

description:
I have only eaten here once, and with that price, I'd rather walk over to Walgreens on Powell Street (which also opens 24 hours a day), get the eggs, bread, and even coffee beans to make my own breakfast...

Definitely catering to the tourists.
author: T L.

description:
OK so... I don't like diners.... but when it's 3am and you're comin back from etd POP @ the Cow Palace early b/c freakin Tiesto cut the power out of the whole damn place and you wanna go to the afterparty @ Ruby, but the line's too long ... and you get damn good parking across the street.... you wander into Pinecrest Diner! hey whaddya know...

so the omelettes are good... strangely enough, the sausage they use was quite tasty! ummmm credit cards yes, prices ok ... $7 minimum is random but doable ... getting to the bathroom is maze like  aaaaand yeah... I recommend it! in the middle of the night! woohoo! 

yup it's 5:34am and i recently got back from all this and just had to review it asap =D
author: Sofia J.

description:
I had "New York Steak and Two Eggs" and it came out MENU-PHOTO PERFECT!!
Authentic All-American Diner and its 24hr!! Serves All Day Breakfast!

I wanted my steak to be medium done, though it came out a bit too dry, but a bottle of "A1" is always the answer for such situation. 

Cozy place to be, warm services~!
author: Andrew W.

description:
They've changed the menu numerous times.  Either that or I suffer from perpetual late night amnesia.

Convenient location, average price, blah interior, usually no waiting late night, decent service and just good 'ol fashioned greasy food aka a real diner.  They don't do chicken fried steak any longer and the steak and eggs are way over-priced now, but I've recently become fond of their corned beef hash.

Drunkards/heel-wearers beware: the bathroom is like 3 flights of stairs down

Spongebob Awesomeness: 3 krabby patties with lots of tabasco sauce, over-medium
author: Ronald M.

description:
We came in here because we just needed to find something quick.  At first glance the prices were too high.  At second glance...they were still too high.  

It was kind of cool winding my way down and around to find the bathroom in the basement. 

All and all this just seems like a sad place that puts no effort into their over priced food.
author: Levi B.

description: This was EXACTLY what we needed this morning (ok, afternoon) after a night out in the city. Is it gourmet cuisine? No, but you'd hardly expect that. The prices were fine - under $10 for two eggs, sausage, hash browns and toast - and the food was solid. Plus, even at noon on a Sunday, we got quick service. I wouldn't make a special trip out here, but if you're in the area and craving standard diner/coffee shop fare, this is a good spot for it.
author: Emily W.

description: After working at the club, we head here around 330 in the morning. The place is packed with workers drunks and party goers and ur steady neighborhood rift rafts and homeless people. The food is good considering its open for 24 hours. The breakfasts are good along with burgers and there kick ass fried chicken it comes with fries along with a salad or soup (those are sub par). Service can be a little slow but hell its 330 in the morning and the place is packed.
author: Jorm K.

description:
Very expensive for what you get, but I've always wondered what a Five-Dollar Shake tastes like.

(Answer:  A three-dollar shake)
author: Pat S.

description: after a long drive and frustrating time having the hotel it was nice to sit down for a hot meal. chicken fried steak with sunny side eggs and hashbrown yumm. sister got app combo- fried zucchini chicken tenders onion rings and cheese sticks yums great place okay service reasonably priced for that area
author: Lynn H.

description: More like 3-1/2 stars.  I went there for breakfast on Monday, 9 December, before 7.  I ordered the chorizo and eggs; the quality of food was very good.  The service was a bit inattentive, especially at the cash register, where the cashier lady (owner's wife?) insisted on finishing counting the cash in the drawer before she would ring me up.  Prices seemed a tad high, but, of course, I'm used to small-town prices for breakfast.   I'd probably go back but be inclined to avoid crowded times there.
author: Danny B.

description: Had breakfast at this great little diner.  It is definitely a diner.  Makes you think of the Edward Hopper painting of a the diner on the corner, except there are lots of people in this place.  Food is good, service is fast, and the coffee is hot.   The place is open 24/7, it's clean, very compact.  I would go back again for a good breakfast.  As for other meals, probably not as there are too many good places to eat in this downtown location, and I would want something besides diner food.
author: Delaine Z.

description:
DON'T JUDGE A BOOK BY IT'S COVER

THE GOOD:
-24 hours
-Clean
-Unassuming and chill vibes
-Doesn't get all the drunks that Mason Cafe across the st. gets
-Doesn't get all the packed madness that Lori's across the st. gets
-Staff is cool 

THE BAD:
-Bathroom is down way downstairs and very small.
-Too many people asking for handouts in the front
-Fries

THE DECISION:
This place use to be pretty ghetto a few years back. They've since upgraded and refaced the joint.  They've also done something with their menu.  It's the bomb now!  It's a bit more pricey but hey...it's really good food!  Seriously! I'd take it any day of the week over Lori's or Mason St. Cafe or even Naan & Curry which are within a block from Pinecrest.  

The ingredients are fresh. The quality of the meat, poultry and produce is noticeably higher grade than the other aforementioned restaurants above. It's truly a "no-nonsense" place to eat during the wee hours of the morning. You can chill in there too cause they've got 2 large plasma screen TV's which the above mentioned restaurants don't  as well. It's comfortable. Not all loud.  Not all frantic. Somehow it seems to attract an older crowd while Cafe Mason and Lori's attracts a   younger, disrespectful, drunk crowd...or at least that's what I've observed in my experience.  Hey, I've been the drunk, younger and disrespectful person in there once in a while back in the days too so... I apologize for that.  The one bad thing is their bathroom.  It's really small and all the way in the basement.  I wish they had more stalls cause I could only imagine how the wait might be after a night of drinking...yikes!

These days, I'm more about chillin' and getting good quality food and a relaxed atmosphere for the price I'm paying.  So, Pinecrest all the way.

***Oh and did I mention the owner of this place also owns Boulevard? 
If the owner can run Boulevard than you've better believe the quality and care of the ingredients at Pinecrest are held to a higher standard!
author: Grubbinator A.

description: It was a diner I have been to better I have been to worse.  However the wait staff was friendly and pretty fast.
author: Micah M.

description:
The worst of the many all night restaurants and diners clustering around Union Square.  Under salted, under peppered, under flavored and overpriced.  Condiments out on every table means as long as you order something that goes with Heinz Ketchup and Tabasco it can only get so bad.  Whatever you do, it is not in good taste to order poached eggs here.  Not funny.  Don't even think of it.

February 2007 update.  Giant vats of snot!
author: Gil S.

description:
If you are awake at 2am, and you are as inebriated as you have ever been at a concert at the Great American, and you don't get to go home because one random interloper from your apartment and another random interloper from Bethesda or some place I cannot recall demand that you stagger with them to find their ladyfriends, you do so.

And if you have to stumble into a diner, this is not a bad diner to do so.

I saw a lot of food pass under my trembling, near ill lips.  Burgers, milkshakes, chocolate cake.  I honestly cannot remember everything that hit the table, but most of it made me want to be ill, while the other part of me knew I needed fuel... to make it to bed instead of hell.

So I methodically slur chewed and fed myself the soggied catsup cheese fry or two, or ate a small piece of syrup drenched bacon.

I would be back here... anytime.  That anytime?  Middle of the night time.  And that time will be rare now that I have learned my lesson.

What lesson is that?  Don't go out with people that will make you go to a diner that late.  It is just an ugly thing.  Anyhoo.. I was so drunk and staring agape at others, I almost became the unwitting picker of a fight.

But still... I could have waited a couple hours for Art's back home.  That is what my five star is waiting for.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: Great portions, had enough for lunch the next day (I eat little so take that with a grain of salt). Asked for medium-done burger and was done exactly so, melting cheese over juicy mushrooms =9
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Honestly, there isn't anything that remarkable about this place.  The food is average.  The bathroom is in the dank, mildewy basement and always out of soap.  The service is alright.  I think I used to like this place because of the laminated picture menu that hadn't changed since the 70s, before food styling emerged as a trade.  The food tasted better when I ordered it by looking at the slightly faded, plastic photo of the perfect hamburger, fried chicken, or sunny side up eggs.  Now the menus are laserprinted and put in plastic covers--no personality, no nostalgia, not so much reason to come here.

UPDATE 9/19/06:  I'm changing my stars from three to one.  This place has gone downhill fast.  Now, it costs $7.25 to get an order of two eggs, hash browns, and toast--WHY??  The omelets, which is basically an unscrambled scramble (as opposed to a skillfully folded omelet), are $9.95.  Those prices can be justified if they're made with haute ingredients, but it's just regular eggs and frozen hash browns slung on a plate.  They were horrible at coffee warmups, too.  It's sad, but I don't think I'll ever eat here again unless I'm desperately hungry and in the neighborhood at 4am.
author: maiko h.

description:
24 hour breakfast.  Probably the best mushroom omlette I've ever had.  If not the best - pretty damn good.  It's always a good sign when a huge omlette is literally falling apart because it has so much filling in it - at least I think so.

I also like the cheeseburger, which is especially good after a night of drinking.

The coffee is also very good - and refills are never long in coming.

The food is decent, so are the prices (check out the Max's Menu across the street).  I've neither been over or underwhelmed by this establishment.  Some of my friends think it has a stigma because of the tragedy, but I think it adds to the lore.

Good food, decent service, good prices - a coffee shop worthy of LA, a town that knows it's coffee shops, but squatting here in SF, lucky for us.
author: Suze C.

description:
I came here at 3am on August 12, 2007 after a night of drinking and dancing for a bachlorette party. We walked here from the Parc 55 hotel and totally enjoyed the breakfast. Maybe it was a little pricey but at 3am who cares!... just hand me my greasy diner food so I can he happy.  :) 

After this I've been to Sparky's and Orphan Andy's and I think this is the best bet for late night diners open in SF.
author: Lorraine B.

description:
The food here was mediocre and expensive. They say they serve the "best breakfast in San Francisco" but really, it's not.

Only good for the local lore that goes along with it. Other than that, stay clear. You're better off getting something at Jack in the Box across the street.
author: Aaron M.

description: WORST DINNER! If Yelp was able to give this 0 stars I wouldn't hesitate to rate this place as so. Came in and ordered a bacon cheese burger which was priced at 10.95. Saw it on the bill which was priced at 11.95. I knew something was not adding up so I picked up another menu where the burger price had been hand written in at 11.95. So I politely asked the server (a big man with a fedora and facial hair) why I had to pay the 11.95 when the menu that was given to me stated otherwise. He called me a dick in front of all other customers told me it was only a dollar more. Asked me to pay and to get the fuck out. He even told me that he would remember me next time I came in. (As if I will come back again after his trashy behavior) . The staff there are all crooks and obviously are hot headed and classless. I warn everyone. The food tasted extremely bland, not special one bit. They will take your money and give you the finger right in your face.
author: Mike D.

description: Serves the purpose for a late night grease fest, in order to put something in your belly.  Service was sufficient, and the food was ok.
author: J. G.

description: Best Breakfast ever and sooo cheap! I went this past Sunday and they were really packed. Our waitress was very nice and friendly. I lovvvved there hashbrowns. Were made perfectly a long with the crispy bacon. MMMM goodness!
author: Yadira G.

description:
(This experience was a few years ago.)

My friends and I got horrible serivce from an insulting and arrogant waitress. I was so angry by the time I left I wanted to throw the crappy food at her. I observed her behavior with other groups and decided that she pre-judged us as people not be served but to serve her. We were too nice to keep our mouths shut. Never again. Go to Lori's Diner instead.
author: Lotte D.

description: I visit Pinecrest everytime Im in the city.  Great greasy spoon food after a night out.  Gets really busy late at night on weekends..   Breakfast is the best there, large portions, and great service.
author: Rixtur R.

description: This place was great. Nothing fancy obviously, but absolutely perfect for a quick breakfast with friendly, efficient service. My coffee cup was never empty and the food was above-average, standard breakfast food.
author: Justin L.

description: Perfect place for that late night craving, especially after a long night out. The diner brings me back to the bustle and environment of NJ diners. I ordered my usual, 2 eggs over easy with bacon, hash browns and toast - the result hit the spot. Service was great. The manager even went above and beyond to fax me an itemized receipt I forgot to request during my visit.
author: Stephanie L.

description: I wish I would have known about the Yelp deal! I would have loved a free appetizer, but I was pretty darned stuffed with the veggie sandwich. The mushroom, avocado, mozzarella, oh man it was all so delicious. They even had really great homemade ranch that went wonderfully with the sandwich and crispy french fries. I would definitely return, was a real deal for about 12.00 dollars to be full all day in the city!
author: Kat B.

description: 9pm on a Saturday night and the place was packed. The food was good although service was a tad bit slow. It was busy though. Beware that those chocolate chips in your pancakes are an extra $2 :-)
author: Kurt W.

description: Do not get the steak and eggs... My friend got it... It looked awful and he said it tasted like rubber. Also another friend got an omlete and it wasn't tasty. Denny's sounds better.
author: Karen T.

description:
the food isn't the best, the service isn't either, and the ambiance isn't something this place should even be rated on.

everything was pretty mediocre and they forgot to bring me a decaf coffee. i guess i didn't really need it.
author: Ameer N.

description: This was definitely diner food, but what I really liked about it was the quiet!  No music, no loud t.v., nothing like that!  Just a nice quiet place to eat in one of the loudest areas of S.F.!  And it was busy too!
author: Don S.

description: I decided to try this place after going to see the midnight showing of The Hobbit. Terrible idea. The floor and tables were sticky, the ground was sticky and dirty. I should have just left right away, but I always try to give places the benefit of the doubt. This time it bit me straight in the butt. The service was HORRIBLE. There seemed to be one guy waiting tables and taking orders, which was fine, there were only a few people in there. But he seemed to neglect everyone! Our food took forever, and when it came, he forgot half the order. We ate, the food was sub-standard (I really didnt expect much from a 24 hour diner, but it was still way under sup-par quality) When we tried to leave the guy would not ring us up! He walked back and forth past the register, to other guests, to the kitchen, but would not help us. We waited for a good 20 minutes before he decided to help us. i shoudl have just gone to Denny's.
author: Ashley H.

description: Even though SF local friends of mines told me this place blew, I grubbed on their country fried steak plate and it was good. Good place to grinds late night when lots of eateries are closed for the nite.
author: Lndn O.

description: The food wasn't anything special. We asked the waitress to split the bill up for us and she was full of attitude. Told us it would take too long and then proceeded to split it in 30 seconds. Oops, probably shouldn't have been so rude seconds before we were to write in your tip on our credit card receipts.
author: Heather H.

description: I love Pinecrest, I've been to most breakfast places in the area and Pinecrest is my favourite, good price and tasty food.
author: Pedro S.

description: one of my eateries by work, love 24 hour breakfast, and the food is decent.  Prices are fair for what you get, and the staff is friendly.  Place is always busy so be prepared to wait for a table.
author: Michael I.

description: Horrible service. Food tastes like it came from the fast food chain that is literally half a block away and a 1/3 of the price. Should have wasted my money on another drink at the bar across the street.
author: Maureen S.

description: Pinecrest Diner is a breakfast gem that we found thanks to Yelp!  It is a little diner right off of Union Square, and has delicious breakfast food!  We went around 11am and it was still busy, but we sat down at the counter, and even a party of 6 was seated within 10 minutes!  Pretty awesome!  We sat on the counter right in front of the grill and were able to see all of the pancakes, bacon, and golden hash browns being prepared and I have to say the delicious smells coming 2 feet from us were making us salivate!  I got the short stack of chocolate chip pancakes and a side of hash browns, while my boyfriend got the Pinecrest Special, which included 2 pancakes (add toppings - fresh fruit or chocolate chips for $2 extra), 2 pieces of bacon or sausage, and 2 eggs any style.  The chocolate chip pancakes were excellent with just the right amount of chocolate chips.  They put chocolate chips in the batter AND sprinkle them on top!!  I also asked for some whipped cream, and the waitress sprayed it right on top of my pancakes...DELISH!!  My hash browns were perfectly golden brown and crispy on top and soft on the inside.  I tried some of the bacon, and I have to say it was nice to see that they make the bacon to order (because I saw it happen in front of me), and you could taste the difference.  The bacon was perfectly salty and crisp!  My boyfriend also ordered chocolate milk, which was disappointing because it came out kind of warm, and the waitress put the glass of milk in a cup of ice to "cool it down" but of course it didn't do anything.  Our waitress was very nice, but she was not super attentive, and we had to flag her down a few times.
author: Jennifer D.

description: For the price, the overall quality can't be beat. Considering  where it is(Union Square) where its mostly chains, serving, a lot of processed food, this area is a toursist trap, down there. If you are a tourist, visiting the area, you would be lucky to find this place and pay 8 bucks, for a Niman Ranch all natural beef, hamburger. Get the cheeseburger.The burgers are def the best choice here, but the Greek salad, Chicken Gyro, and Med plate, are fresh and tasty.
author: Joe N.

description: So It's late night. We are starvng and this place gives us the WORST food that I have had in my 19 months here in SF. Honestly We ordered nachos and buffalo wings... not the best quality entrees to order but usually you cant screw these up. The cheese on the nachos was canned nacho cheese an they didn't even bother  to heat it up it was COLD and LUMPY we didn't even eat it. We even asked them to heat it up. Buffalo wings were typical and also COLD. Service... poor it took forever to even get order in or for the server to take the drink order. If I could give no stars I would. The best part of the meal was the root beer float and all you do is pour rootbeer into a glass with a couple of scoops of ice cream. If they screwed that up... i mean sheesh. It was terrible. One of the worst dining experiences EVER
author: Stephfon B.

description: I have actually never had this happen before, but I walked into the diner around 6 am, it was mostly empty including a couple of small tables for two people each. I was told that I had to sit at the counter. When I asked about sitting at a table (since I had a bunch of stuff with me that wouldn't fit at the counter) I was refused in a very rude way, so I left.
author: Laura S.

description: Good ol' American breakfast!!  Delicious, hot and plentiful. Great place to sit & people watch while enjoying 'diner' food at it's finest. Love the slight retro feel of it too...very cool. A must if you like 'comfort food' and are staying in the area. Enjoy!
author: Marlo R.

description: The food was okay but I have had better. You do not get much portion compare to what you pay. The glass of cranberry juice was ridiculously high, it was $4.25 a glass. There are better choice within the area for better quality of food. The service was mediocre. I would not go back here.
author: Anh N.

description: A better drunken meal is hard to find. The Pinecrest has breakfast all day and a good selection of dinner-esque options. Everything I've had here has been quite tasty but that could just be the booze talking. The service was speedy and the people watching is top notch!
author: Lee S.

description: Went there with my mom for breakfast and we were seated relatively quickly.  The place was busy, but no line out the door or anything. We both ordered the french toast and a side of scrambled eggs, and given that their sign claims that they have "the best breakfast in town," my expectations of good food were not out of line.  The french toast was pathetic.  In a city known for amazing bread, they used thin grocery store white sandwich bread for their french toast.  They didn't put any spices in the batter and it was just a bland.  The price was not cheap either.  I would never go back and I would never recommend that anyone go here.  We seriously would have had a more satisfying breakfast across the street at Jack in the Box.
author: NS W.

description: I came to this place after ruby skye. It was either this or lori's diner across the street. The smell of bacon attracted me to this place. Drunk and starving I ordered a pinecrest special which is basically an 11 dollar grand slam. I only liked the bacon. The rest were sub par. If it was dennys maybe this place would be a 3 star but it should be 5.99 not almost 2x as much. I also ordered a side of hash browns. No flavor at all. So bland with a charred outside and a hard undercooked inside.
author: chris c.

description: Great spot for breakfast.  Homefries were awesome.  Nice location near Union Square, which made for a nice walk after breakfast.
author: Todd S.

description: The sign says they have the best breakfast in San Francisco, I beg to disagree. The breakfast options were limited. Greasy spoon  and wasn't anything special. I did like the classic diner atmosphere but other than that, not too impressed. Think food production line. Would probably give it a 2.5 star rating if I could.
author: Tasha O.

description:
I have only ordered the cheese burger here and it arrives everytime with fresh lettuce and tomato and tastes just fine.

I may be there a little tooo ooften as one of the servers  brings me my beverage with out even asking.. hmmm...

handie location, 24x7, burger fix, simple happy me.
author: mof m.

description:
Okay, when I first moved to San Francisco, I was pretty sketchy about this place. Then after a long night of going out with friends, we decided to stop here..
Glad we did!!
I hate pancakes, but this place....
this place sold me on the pancakes.
That and you can share! So..
a short stack, with a side of sausage or whatever makes you happy, and you can share with a friend.
;x
and the hot chocolates are good too!
author: Jess L.

description: Went for breakfast. Food good, service: what you'd expect.  Denver omelet was lovely.   Cheeze food instead of cheese?  Not sure, but it was yummy.  Servers work very hard here, but they were sunny.  Don't expect customized service. If you sit at the counter by the grill, be prepared to feel the heat.
author: Patrick M.

description: I ate here while in SF for Dreamforce 2010. The service wasn't terribly quick but the food was good and the place was clean. It also wasn't busy so it was nice to be able to talk without having to scream. I ordered the burger and fries and my friend ordered the rueben. Both were really good. If I was in the area, I would definitely go again.
author: Heath B.

description: Dottie's was closed on Tuesday, and Mike and I were in desparate need of hangover food so we wandered around the vicinity of union square near our hotel and found Pinecrest Diner. I felt the prices were a little steep for mediocre food. The menu really wasn't' anything special. I got the Spanish omelette and Mike got a combo of French toast, bacon and eggs. The portions were generous, but I'd rather eat at Dottie's.
author: Mel C.

description: Go to Jack in the Box across the street and for 1/2 the price you get the same type of food. I have to give a star for the somewhat friendliness of the service. I'd say this could be a place for tourists to leave their hard earned dollars.
author: Greg M.

description: Great little diner. Small but clean. Food was good. Being open 24hrs in this area is a plus.
author: Mike B.

description:
Ahhh .... a greasy spoon in the middle of San Francisco and to be fair it wasn't that bad. We went in because of a coupon in one of the free travel guides which gave us 20% off. We ordered a hamburger and hot dog which came with fries but we changed the fries for onion rings for an extra $1.50 each. 

The service was really non existing. It could be better but again to be fair its not somewhere where you expect a silver service. 

Its not that cheap either. It came to over $21.00 after the discount. I always feel like a cheap dirty bastard when I use coupons. 

Its convenient in its location and 24 hours.
author: Benjamin L.

description: Decent, hardly healthy diner food that satisfy the drunk soul during late hours. They got the breakfasts, sandwiches, fried chicken-the usual suspects in a diner. Good old school place to go to sober up the DD.
author: Ed L.

description: Arriving early for the theater one evening, we stopped in here for a cup of coffee, and I felt like I needed a shower after we left. As dirty as the place looked and as greasy as it smelled, it was immaculate compared to the filthy hell hole of a bathroom, which had neither soap nor paper towels, leaving me to wonder how employees compelled by law to wash their hands before leaving the facilities managed to do so. The very thought of eating here made me queasy, and I wouldn't tempt fate by actually doing so.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
i love the idea of all-nite dining but this was really mediocre for the price. i mean, how can you screw up eggs? even I can cook that. should've gotten a burger but something about places like this makes you think you need breakfast!
really good coffee, though. surprised me.
author: Jeremy D.

description: Food came out fast. Ate the breakfast sandwiches. It did the job for diner food.
author: Darla V.

description: Fuckface and I stumbled across this diner on a busy Friday lunchtime. The place was packed but we were seated remarkably quickly. I was surprised by how grotty the decor was; this is an "authentic" diner in the "sticky floors and tables, crumbs on the table, greasy menus" sense of the word. The server was friendly enough but seemed harried and under pressure. We both opted for the Club sadwich, and asked for cheese with it; it came without. It was a pretty big sandwich but the turkey wasn't the best quality. After tip and tax, the lunch came to $38 which was completely overpriced. I guess if I was drunk or high, I wouldn't have cared : /
author: Caroline C.

description: I admit:  it was 2 or 3 or maybe later.  I have no idea why my friend from NY (a great late-night guy of course) wanted breakfast just hours after a full dinner at an entirely-civilized 8:30-ish.  It probably was the  the mandatory take-the-visitor-to-Coit-Tower (after driving full speed down Lombard), followed by drinks at Mario's, and I'm sure elsewhere.  It just seemed like a good idea.  And he was the happiest camper.  I just had bites, but it seemed (at that late hour) the perfect diner experience.  It's not quite the Greek diners we used to frequent in New York (with excellent bagels and fresh-squeezed OJ for pennies), but it was very good.  A late-night winner!
author: Laurel B.

description: While on vacation, I ate breakfast here twice.  The first time I sat at the counter.  I ordered a cheese omelet which came with has browns and my choice of bread for $9.25.  I also ordered coffee for $2.25 with free refills if you ordered a meal.  I am a breakfast person and I have to say I was very pleased with my meal.  The omelet took up half of the plate and the has browns the other.  I usually don't like to sit at the counter but it gave me an I site into the diner ops.  The staff exchanged friendly banter with each other and the cook worked effortlessly assembling the orders.  The gentlemen that ran the show, seated customers, tok orders, delivered food and anything else that needed to be done.  I learned that he was bilingual when a customer seemed to struggle with English and he proceeded to converse in her language.  He assisted her with providing her with transportation information as well as info about the places she was going to visit.  He was very pleasant and engaging with the customers.  My second visit, i had their 2 eggs, 2 pieces of bacon AND sausage and 2 pancakes.  I enjoyed this meal also.  Yes, this is a diner with good diner food.  The corner location provides great people watching and is conveniently located a few blocks from Union Square.
author: Cleo G.

description: This place had a great breakfast waiting for me one morning.  That isn't always the easiest thing to find.  Pretty solid.
author: Cliff M.

description: The service was slow. It took maybe twenty five minutes to get bacon and eggs. Also, those orange juices are five dollars a glass. I was thirsty so it was pretty expensive. However, the food is good and the place has a friendly atmosphere.
author: Jason W.

description: The Pinecrest lives that others may die, or so it might appear.  This place should be on life support, but it somehow survives year after year in spite of gross mediocrity in food, service and atmosphere.  Home to the infamous poached egg murder in 1997, it feels like they are preserving it for evidence in a trial in hell sometime in the faraway future.  The burger is OK but dreary like the decor if anyone dare call it that.  There is a despair and pained urban grayness to everything about this place, and it only breathes when the theaters next door let out or when clubbers leave Ruby Skyy or Biscuits and Blues nearby.  There is a curiosity seeking clientele along with social security recipients living in the Tenderloin that separates it from Union Square.
author: Stu S.

description: This joint is kind of Seinfeldy, and the meats are very high quality (so they claim - Niman Ranch). It's good stuff if you aren't expecting too much.
author: Jason M.

description: This place has been around for as long as I can remember.  Nothing fancy.  Just good old diner fair.  Something simple after a show includes two huge buttermilk pancakes and a side of sausage.   Hubby had a ham and cheese omelet - delish!  Hash browns were a little undercooked.
author: Denise M.

description:
The Pinecrest is a unique establishment that I have visited a number of times, only to be underwhelmed every single time.  The food is marginal, and the service is worse.

So why, might you ask, does an obviously intelligent gentleman such as myself continue to go?  Thats a damn good question, Virginia, and the answers are twain:

1) Open all night in an area where not much else is.  
So you stumbled out of Biscuits and Blues or Ruby Skye in the middle of the night?  You came out of the theater with a hankering for some grease? Not a lot of options.  Also, the place is bright and homey, exactly what you want in the middle of the night

2) Narcissism. So the Pinecrest has an ignominious past that few people know, but I do.  And I like to tell the story.  Apparently I like the kitsch of telling the story, having it validated and feeling local, wise, and salty enough to return here.  

Read the version of the story by Mister SF here (http://mistersf.com/notorious/index.html?notpinecrest.htm).

Needless to say, once you have read it do the following
1. Commit to memory
2. Work on precisely the sexiest way to tell it, starting with all kinds of secrecy and a build up to the punch line
3. When you wind up in the neighborhood in the middle of the night, tell your friends you know a spot and bring them here.
4.  Tell your friends the food is awful, but tell them the story, as you worked it out in your own personal idiom of course.
5. Point out the picture and try to order poached eggs
6. Your friends will be impressed by your knowledge of local lore, and not fault you for the food or the price, you warned them after all.
author: Victor B.

description: Bad service. Disgusting food. I had to ask at least three times for my coffee and my omelette was swimming in grease. I was so hungry, I forced myself to eat it and I felt like gagging afterwards. The server was snobby and not courteous at all. Breakfast is better off at Lori's Diner across the street, where there is better service and their omelettes aren't glazed with oil. The only pro was that I was seated promptly---but that's only because there was no one else dining there. I would never come here again.
author: Zell C.

description: This place was not right.  Came here super wasted (of course) one weekend night.  I ordered the chili cheese burger, and it was nasty.  The bread was tough, the patty tougher, and the whole thing was just wrong.  I usually am so hungry late night that I'll eat just about whatevers, but this was beyond that.
author: Sarah F.

description: Anyone who grew up on the east coast knows what a TRUE grilled cheese sandwich is & for those of you who don't, this is the formula: white bread, american cheese & tomato. That's it. If you're super hungry, you can get the "happy waitress" and add bacon. It's consumed with a side of fries, a buttload of ketchup and a cup of coffee. You should leave the diner with enouch money for a bottle of Bud or PBR. Most places in SF, however, mess up this formula and offer grilled cheese with cheddar or with many different kinds of cheese, or with sourdough of all things. And there is a time and a place for fancy grilled cheese (I prefer mine w/ fresh mozza, roma tomatoes and focaccia) but sometimes you need the real shit. Pine Crest has the real shit. And for that, I love them.
author: Maria D.

description:
We found this place wandering around the city on a lazy Sunday afternoon because Dottie's had a longggg line out the door. We should've known not to go in after the homeless guy outside the door recommended that it was "quick and tasty" and that when he was able to accumulate enough change he would go in for a bite to eat. 

I ordered the Pinecrest omelet with egg whites and a glass of grapefruit juice. The omelet had bacon, sausage, and ham with toast and hash browns on the side. The grapefruit juice was pretty tasteless - neither sweet nor sour. The omelet was very watery; I had to soak up all the water with my napkin. The toast was over buttered for my taste because I like to have spread jelly on my toast. 

I would not come here again; once is more than enough.
author: D L.

description:
My wife and I come to San Francisco occassionally and each visit we come here the first night to sample the traditional diner fare. It has been a few years between visits, looks the same but the faces of the employees have changed, no big supprise there. The place was clean and service good. The food, great, nothing to fancy we both had burgers and they arrived quickly, all the bits were fresh and tasty the burgers were cooked as requested, the fries were fresh and crisp and the beer was cold, what more can you ask.

If you are looking for high end culinary fare this is not it, there are plenty of other places to fill that bill in this fine city. But if you are looking for a burger in a relaxed diner atmosphere then this fits the bill. Speaking of bill, 2 burgers, 2 beers, tax and tip $38. I don't think this to be excessive for the quality and it is in San Francisco.
author: Garry P.

description:
On some other websites where this is reviewed, most people say that they were trashed  while dining at 3 am, and the reviews are wonderful.
I went at around 12:30, sober, and, well, it was okay. I little expensive in my opinion. There's a 7 dollar minimum per person. It's a 24 hour diner...and they have a minimum?. That's a little fishy in the first place.
10 dollars for an omelet with hash browns. I didn't care, I was hungry. Both omelet and hash browns, however, turned out to be delectable. I got a 5 dollar milkshake, too. Just okay, and small. They charge 4.50 for a bagel and a packet of Philadelphia cream cheese.
All right, I'm cheap, I'll be quiet. 
The crowd was interesting though, it's right next to a theater. When we left, about 4 homeless peddlers approached us before we got into the car. We parked 4 spaces away from the door!
Basically, it's like Denny's, only better quality food. And service. Our waitress probably spoke six words of English, but our food came quick and hot.
author: Diana H.

description: Hm. After reading the admittedly entertaining, but markedly negative reviews of the Pine Crest, I almost didn't go -- but the pull of Yet Another San Francisco Story drew me in, and so my partner and I found ourselves there at 10:30 pm on a Sunday.  Apparantly this is the perfect time to give the place custom, 'cause neither of us had a single complaint. My grilled cheese was close to melty cheese and toasted bread perfection, my partner's hash browns (despite the warnings that we'd have to blot the grease off of them) were cooked perfectly and not too greasy at all.  Admittedly, my salad was more what you'd expect from a diner in the Mid-West, but overall I was happy.  Service was FAST and friendly, price was a bit higher than I expected, but still. . .a perfectly good 24-hour dining experience, and really a GREAT, noteworthy grilled cheese.
author: Jude F.

description: this place is great and since its 24 hours its always available. i ordered the vegeterian sandhwich which comes with fries and the sandwhich is filled with mozzerella, avacado,greens, and tomato. very filling sandwhich because sometimes at diners the veggie options are lame not here. not to mention the woman serving us was very nice looking always a plus.
author: Paulringo M.

description: Nice homeless man outside working as a marketing campaign directing people in to the "best breakfast in sf". It was packed so we opted to try it. Sat fairly quickly - less than 5 minutes. Got Huevos rancheros which was good but the decried beans it is supposed tocome with was actually chili. It was ok though. Wife ha chicken fried steak with hash browns and eggs cooked perfectly. Good spot and fast service.
author: Mickey Z.

description: When you order a 10 dollar omelette you expect it to be at least decent. The only thing good on the plate was the sourdough toast. It was really depressing just being in there. Plus there's two other diners across the street that can't help but mock your poor choice in eatery. Never going back!
author: ceaseless

description: Nothing special here. They're open late and thats about all they have going for 'em. The food is your standard greasy spoon fare, which there's absolutely nothing wrong with, the prices were just a shade high for my taste. I can't deny that I demolished my food while wasted though. Nothing like a late night breakfast to soak up some club drinks. In the end if you have a choice, go with Grubstake.
author: Tommy P.

description: They call themselves the best breakfast place in SF and it is true.  Huge portions and GREAT service. The hash browns are amazing and I have NEVER finihsed a plate of pancakes in my life but I did finish these.  Definitely go HERE for breakfast!!!
author: Eddie V.

description: This is a kickass spot with the best turkey burgers in sf. however - there is one ingredient that it lacks - music ! We would definitely stay longer and spend more if we could enjoy our delicious burger and cold beer with good background music instead of the humming of the cooking equipment.
author: G Q.

description: From all the 3 star reviews I imagine this place can do some things right. When I went with some friends we waited and waited and waited to get a seat. Plenty of people had finished eating, but they also had to play the waiting game with the staff. During our entire meal they were totally non-existent which is too bad because I would have liked to have told someone about how horrible their food was. I have never complained about food in my life, but when I get charged 10$ for the inedible dog-food and processed slice of cheese they call a chili-burger it can get a fella a little upset. Everyone elses food looked equally horrifying, So I guess just now what you are getting yourself into and don't order anything outside of normal breakfast fare.
author: Nick L.

description:
Ammended Review
I just went to Pinecrest recently...they've cut back on the portions and the prices seem higher. my favorite waitress is gone.  it's still open late and it's not terrible, but less appetizing in general.  i'm thinking the sampler platter at Denny's on fourth and mission is a better late night snack in the future.
Original Review
As far as diners go, Pinecrest is my favorite.  Three of the waitresses there, especially one are supernice (one knows that I like a side of bleu cheese with my fries).  You can get seafood to breakfast food and if you tell them how to make it, they'll do it right.  My fav is the grilled cheese and fries.  I also like the cheesburger and fries. They have generous portions and the fries are amazing (they had a brief stint with some bad fries for about a month, but they changed back and it's been all good in the hood since). Best thing is they're open all the time. food comes out FAST too. Also, you can see them cooking so there's a trust issue.  yeah, it's not Lori's or Mason's and thank the Lord almight for that. (although lori's does have hot dogs...)
author: Yvonne Y.

description: i popped in here today, not expecting bliss. it was near where i was and fit budget. jack n' the crack was across the street, but i just can't do it. so, pinecrest. i love the diner feel, but the food!the food! whhhhhhhhy? how can u go wrong with a patty melt i thought. well, here's how: add 4 tablespoons of fake butter, burn the patty, add velveeta, add greasy onions (i realize patty melt is greasy, but this took greasy to a whole other level) then add mayo (shouldn't i have to ask for that?!) when it arrived. i stared at it. i could have sworn it burped at me. i took a bite, put it down, sent it back. here's where the 2 stars come in instead of 1. i ordered a garden salad with a side of dressing. she adjusted the bill and we were square.
author: S. G.

description: Came here for a late night coffee with friends. This place is open 24/7, and reminds me of a quintessential NY diner perched on the corner of some seedy neighborhood with typical seedy diner decor: flood lights, long booth tables with hideous brown vinyl seats, drab carpeting that hasn't been changed out since the 60's, & huge open windows for you to stare out at passerbys. I LUV a greasy spoon, and all I saw were huge bountiful, overflowing plates of perfectly-cut fries, (my weakness), sized between a mcdonald's fry & a UK-sized chip, (aka, in my opinion, the "perfectly-sized fry"), paired with thick, luscious creamy milkshakes...and I starred at this 'eye candy' as I graciously sipped on my decaf coffee...(some of the *best* coffee I've had at a diner yet!). Boo to healthy eating plans & my mission to shed the last of this junk in my trunk...I'll be back to dig in on my cheat day Pinecrest...*don't u worry...
author: Rebecca S.

description: I was staying at a hotel in the area and stopped by for breakfast at around 8:45am. About half the tables were empty. I was told in no uncertain terms to sit at the counter if I was eating alone. Most of the issue was with the rude tone of the waitress. The other thing that annoyed me was that the place was half empty. I found another seat at Lori's across the street and I will post that review. They were lovely.
author: Roberta N.

description: Descent hash browns. Really good greasy eggs. Atmosphere is just Ok. A somewhat weak 4 b/c of the layout.
author: Scott F.

description: Stopped by for breakfast (cause it was a block from the hotel) and ordered the Hot link 'n eggs breakfast: eggs were done the way I ordered, pancakes were standard and the hash browns and hot link were super greasy. Usual fare and usual expectations for a diner. No more, no less. On the plus side, the service was quick and my coffee cup never fell below half...
author: James A.

description:
so i came here with my family 

and we go in and this very good looking charming young waiter

tells us sit where ever we like

umm...... in the booth in the corner he tells us


so im a little confused about that

then he comes to ask us for our drinks

but he pops out of the side of the booth like 

not where ud expect him to be

like hes taking our orders from in the kitchen while bending over the side of our booth

but ig ot me an even better chance stare at him

and he had chest hair poking  out of hi shirt 

cute

meanwhile

i order pasta pomodoro

it tasted like oil

but then again what was i gonna expecct ordering pasta pomodoro 

from a diner

that specializes in hamburgers

meanwhile

after i ate my bowl of oil and garlic

i wanted toast

cause thats what u naturally pair with pasta......sourdough toast

no butter of course

but as i ask him for it

he looks at meand tells me its on the house


ugh i melted

blue eyes

and he scored me free bread

meanwhile

the place was cute

and intimate

i recommend it but dont go getting fancy oranything

stick to burgers and fries

X
author: Mateo X.

description:
Great food.  Runny eggs, bones in the ham steaks, hash that could pass as dog food, and chicken that runs pink.   But and I'll tell you what....They have this smoking hot waitress that looks like Sophia Loren circa 1959.  

I ordered up some steak and eggs and she brought me back some chili that looked like dog sh-t, but who cares?  I ate it and gave her my million dollar smile.  

If you ever go in there and see my boy from da' East Bay waking out in front of her zipping his drawers, you know it was on.  He's all class.

Now can you dig that?..................SUCKAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: TJ R.

description:
People, it's a diner.

It's not Morton's Steakhouse, The Oak Room or Grille 23. Nor does to claim to be anything but a diner.

But a great diner it is. Granted, it is in downtown San Francisco and it does attract many tourists at Breakfast and Lunch.

But, if you live locally. The pinecrest is the ONLY authentic diner to shake a stick at. Food is reasonably priced, ample. The staff are friendly, attentive and you leave here full and satisfied.

If your expectations are higher than 'ample diner food at a reasonable price, served by folks who are friendly and recognize your local face' then you are probably looking for a different type of restaurant and will not appreciate what the PineCrest has to offer.

If you like diners, The PineCrest is your ticket.

Dammit, now I am hungry.....I will be there in 30 mins.....2 eggs over easy, bacon, soudough and coffee.
author: Merkuree M.

description: Came here after Slide. From what I could remember, good. But then again, what isn't at that time of the day. And opened 24 hours. Awesome.
author: Jimmy N.

description: I like the feel of this place as far as late-night diners go, because honestly the Mel's/Lori's bright, fluorescent, cherry-red plastic booths dealio can get a little creepy sometimes. (Too much phoney upbeat-ness after a certain hour of the day. You know, right after waking up.) This is certainly a more down-to-earth version of that and, lo and behold, in the city that always seems to sleep even on those Saturday nights when no one respectable should be, Pinecrest is open 24 hours (hurrah!). I had a sub-par Sundae and herbal tea, which would've been decently priced if it weren't because they were so mediocre, but I really wasn't expecting mind-blowing quality here and was quite simply pleased to just kick it with a friend for an hour for a meager $8. I'd definitely be willing to come back to try some of their actual food, though I'll be sitting somewhere away from the front door, which everybody and their loving mom keeps leaving open to let in that charmingly freezing San Francisco breeze that will turn your nose hairs into icicles.
author: G. J.

description: Get over yourselves....this place gets the job done at 2:00 AM.  The omelettes are yummy and cooked like omelettes are supposed to be.  The hashbrowns are crunchy and the service is good.  You don't come here for the ambience or the decor....you come here because you are hungry and have no need for the dull Lori's Diner or the trashy folks at Jack in the Box.   Don't stare at the locals.....we will bite!  Eat your food, tip and be generous, and drive safely back to your boring suburbs.   Thanks Pine Crest....
author: Demetri A.

description: The pinecrest has some fabulous new healthy additions to the menu.  The portions are all very big and you get your moneys worth. Its a great place to go any time of the day its a 24 hours place!
author: anthoula l.

description: just a normal diner off of union square with the regular black coffee, the standard breakfasts, and the rushed service.  food was pretty good though, and i could see myself utilizing this place after-hours!
author: Jill k.

description: This is the kind of place that you have to be drunk to enjoy.  I was and it still sucked. It was midnight and I was sober enough to order safe. I was served the worst grilled ham and cheese in the history of the United States. Unfortunately, I wasn't sober enough to realize that stopping and losing the $7.95 would have been a better choice than continuing to choke it down. Good news, it only takes 4 hours to totally digest their grilled ham and cheese, so you will be ready for breakfast. Luckily, one of my friends wasn't as sober, and ordered a bowl of chili. Generic canned chili with giant strips of onion and a stack of American Cheese food cut into cubes floating in the grease. Seeing those giant striated blocks of yellow wax slowly melting into his chili made me feel much more content with my frighteningly bad sandwich. The fact that this place has 3 1/2 stars makes me feel faint.  From this day forward I will not eat at a restaurant reviewed on Yelp that has less than 100 reviews and 4 1/2 stars.
author: John P.

description: Call me crazy but I loved this place.  As a displaced New Yorker living in LA, where there is no such thing as a real dive diner, the Pinecrest reminded me of home.  It's nothing to look at.  Just your basic booths and counter with the cooking done right there behind it.  You got your eggs, omlettes, bacon, ham steaks, burgers and hashbrowns flung around all in what seems to be controlled chaos.  Yesterday I came by for take out since my hotel down the block wanted like $25 for eggs (the Clift - I'll be yelping about this place too).  I ordered two eggs over medium and hash browns.  They were perfect.   So today when I had more time, I decided to sit at the counter and enjoy the vibe of this real diner.  For breakfast I had their house omlette (mushrooms/ tomato/american cheese) with egg whites only and asked for them to add spinach.  It was delicious and the hash browns were perfect.  If there was anything to complain about it was that it was HUGE.  No one person could've eaten the whole thing.  All of the ingredients were fresh from the perfectly cooked mushrooms and spinach to the tomatos that had been chopped and seperated from all of their juices to make sure the omlette didn't get watery.  It wasn't cheap...if cost $13 with a diet coke.  But far better than what room service would've set me back and we're in the city - and a pretty touristy part of the city, so whatdya expect?
author: Beth F.

description: a good solid greasy spoon in the heart of San Francisco. be aware of the street folks trying to walk in a sneak off with your coffee. other than that, a solid breakfast place. no nonsense food. served quickly. decent servings with a slice of orange on the side. as always, eat at the counter. that is really the only way to have your pancakes.
author: Virginia A.

description: way back in the day, i use to dine here for lunch with some girl that use to be my lover , she fancied pancakes, i fancied her.
author: Pickle R.

description: I ate here since I was staying at Hotel Diva across the street and I was really really stoned. I was lured by the sign that said "Best Breakfast in San Francisco".  I had just been up to Union Square and the places there were packed as it was a Friday night and tourist season so this seemed like a good idea at the time. It was marginally busy - mostly blue haired old ladies and some young black couples. I sat at the counter and ordered a burger. The waitress was busy so the cook took my order and proceeded to throw the raw meet patty on the grill. It cooked for what seemed like forever. he never washed his hands or anything. The fries were sitting in the basket on the fryer when I arrived.  A few minutes before he assembled my burger he dropped those stale old fries back in the hot grease and warmed them up. The burger came with no condiments or garnish. Just a dry burger on a stale bun with lettuce and tomato. There was a limp pickle wedge on the plate. I ate two bites and that was it. nasty. I will never return.
author: Gary C.
